# Scientific environment

This thesis was conducted at the Department of Biological Sciences, Faculty of Science and Technology, University of Bergen (Norway) as part of the UNESCO Chair on Sustainable Heritage and Environmental Management group. 
I was also affiliated with the Centre for Sustainable Area Management (CeSAM), University of Bergen. 
This work was part of the TradMod project *From traditional resource use to modern industrial production: holistic management in Western Norway* funded by the Research Council of Norway (grant #280299).
Additional funding support was provided by a grant from *Olaf Grolle Olsens's Legat til Universitet i Bergen med tilførsel av arv ette Miranda Bødker*.

# Abstract {#sec-abstract}

As we celebrate the 10^th^ year anniversary of the United Nations' report introducing the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, scientific evidence keeps on demonstrating the unprecedented environmental footprint of agriculture worldwide.
In this context, research effort should focus on gathering knowledge and experience from farming systems which ensure the sustainable use of land resources and the ecological integrity of ecosystems. 
In the fjord region of Western Norway, a long history of low-intensity grazing and diversified farming practices has shaped an agricultural landscape of high ecological diversity and cultural value.
However, the post-WW2 rationalisation of livestock production led to concomitant processes of intensification on more fertile fields and abandonment of remote areas, resulting in a generalised decline of farming activity and area of grazed habitats.
In 2019, the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve was designated as a model area for the regional implementation of the 2030 Agenda Sustainable Development Goals.
This framework motivated research initiatives for the production of actionable knowledge for the sustainable management of land resources in Western Norway.

In line with these perspectives, this thesis aims to assess the influence of environmental and management factors on biodiversity and ecosystem service delivery in grazing-dependent habitats in Western Norway.
I led observational studies on 42 grazing fields distributed across the fjord region of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve to investigate: 
(1) the influence of the environmental gradient on habitat productivity and the composition of grassland communities at regional scale;
(2) the effect of field management, more specifically livestock type and prescribed burning, on the diversity and community composition of semi-natural grasslands and heathlands respectively;
and (3) the synergies and trade-offs between indicators of biodiversity and ecosystem services in the agroecological landscape of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve.

I confirmed that the combination of topographic and climatic constraints of the fjord region generates a hump-shaped pattern of aboveground productivity from west to east by limiting forage availability on the outer coastal and mountain areas.
However, I found no evidence that the regional environmental gradients influenced the taxonomic or functional composition of semi-natural grasslands as an independent factor.
Regarding field management, I observed that livestock type affected the cover of plant functional groups, with higher grass cover in cattle-grazed fields, but showed no direct effect on vascular plant species richness or the composition of dominant grass, forb and beetle assemblages.
However, dominant plant assemblages were consistently correlated with the fine-scale environment of grazing fields, which itself was weakly correlated with field management.
This finding may indicate an indirect link between grazing management and plant communities in semi-natural grasslands, but whose direction remains to be determined.
In coastal heathlands, I found that xerophilous and sun-loving beetle species were more active on recently burnt patches, and I was able to determine new indicator species for both pioneer and mature heath phases.
I also added to the evidence that traditional prescribed burning contributed to the heterogeneity of heathland ecosystems at regional scale.
Finally, I observed a productivity-diversity trade-off between semi-natural grasslands and heathlands across the agroecological landscape of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve.
Semi-natural heathlands were characterised by higher plant diversity, and semi-natural grasslands by greater forage availability.
I also showed that both habitat types supported the delivery of regulating services.
I found higher soil carbon content and cryptogam diversity in semi-natural heathlands, adding to the evidence that nutrient-poor habitats are essential contributors to climate regulation and water storage.
In semi-natural grasslands, I observed a synergy between trait-based indicators of nectar resource and forage resource, indicating that higher productivity does not erode pollinator food availability.

Overall, I demonstrated that semi-natural grasslands and heathlands in the Nordhorldand UNESCO Biosphere Reserve supported the delivery of complementary ecosystem services across the fjord landscape.
I emphasized that further research is needed for deepening our understanding of the complex interactions between the farmer, the livestock and the environment in small-scale grazing systems.
I recommend that methodological frameworks should be designed to capture the inherent variability of agroecological systems, by developing farm-scale assessments and transdisciplinary approaches.
Collaborative knowledge-building and inclusive policy-making in the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve are necessary to support sustainable food production and the conservation of agroecosystems in Western Norway.

# Sammendrag

Når vi feirer 10-årsjubileet for FN-rapporten som introduserte Agenda 2030 for bærekraftig utvikling, viser vitenskapelige beviser stadig det enestående miljøavtrykket som landbruket har på verdensbasis.
I denne sammenheng bør forskningsinnsatsen fokusere på å samle kunnskap og erfaring fra landbrukssystemer som sikrer bærekraftig bruk av landressurser og økosystemers økologiske integritet. 
I fjordregionen på Vestlandet har en lang historie med lavintensiv beitebruk og diversifiserte jordbruksmetoder formet et jordbrukslandskap med stor økologisk mangfold og kulturell verdi.
Rasjonaliseringen av husdyrproduksjonen etter andre verdenskrig førte imidlertid til en intensivering av driften på mer fruktbare åkrer og en nedleggelse av fjerntliggende områder, noe som resulterte i en generell nedgang i jordbruksaktiviteten og arealet med beiteområder.
I 2019 ble Nordhordland UNESCO Biosfæreområde utpekt som modellområde for regional implementering av bærekraftsmålene i Agenda 2030.
Dette rammeverket motiverte til forskningsinitiativer for produksjon av handlingsrettet kunnskap for bærekraftig forvaltning av landressurser på Vestlandet.

I tråd med disse perspektivene har denne avhandlingen som mål å vurdere innflytelsen fra miljø- og forvaltningsfaktorer på biologisk mangfold og økosystemtjenester i beiteavhengige habitater på Vestlandet.
Jeg ledet observasjonsstudier i 42 beiteområder fordelt over fjordregionen i Nordhordland UNESCO Biosfæreområde for å undersøke: 
(1) innflytelsen fra miljøgradienten på habitatproduktivitet og sammensetningen av gressmarkssamfunn på regional skala;
(2) effekten av forvaltning, nærmere bestemt husdyrtype og kontrollert brenning, på mangfoldet og sammensetningen av henholdsvis seminaturlige beitemarker og lyngheier;
og (3) synergiene og avveiningene mellom indikatorer for biologisk mangfold og økosystemtjenester i det agroøkologiske landskapet i Nordhordland UNESCO Biosfæreområde.

Jeg bekreftet at kombinasjonen av topografiske og klimatiske begrensninger i fjordregionen skaper et pukkelformet mønster av produktivitet over bakken fra vest til øst ved å begrense tilgangen på fôr i de ytre kyst- og fjellområdene.
Jeg fant imidlertid ingen bevis for at det regionale miljøgradienter påvirket den taksonomiske eller funksjonelle sammensetningen av semi-naturlige beitemarker som en uavhengig faktor.
Når det gjelder forvaltning, observerte jeg at husdyrtypen påvirket dekningen av plantefunksjonelle grupper, med høyere gressdekke i felt som ble beitet av storfe, men viste ingen direkte effekt på artsrikdommen av karplanter eller sammensetningen av dominerende gress-, urte- og billesamfunn.
Imidlertid var dominerende plantesamfunn konsekvent korrelert med det finmaskede miljøet i beitene, som i seg selv var svakt korrelert med forvaltningen.
Dette funnet kan tyde på en indirekte sammenheng mellom beiteforvaltning og plantesamfunn i seminaturlige beitemarker, men retningen på denne sammenhengen gjenstår å fastslå.
I kystnære lyngheier fant jeg ut at xerofile og solelskende biller var mer aktive på nylig brente områder, og jeg kunne fastslå nye indikatorarter for både pioner- og modne heiefaser.
Jeg bidro også til bevisene for at tradisjonell kontrollert brenning bidro til heterogeniteten i heiøkosystemer på regionalt nivå.
Til slutt observerte jeg en avveining mellom produktivitet og mangfold mellom seminaturlige beitemarker og lyngheier i det agroøkologiske landskapet i Nordhordland UNESCOs Biosfæreområde.
Seminaturlige lyngheier var preget av større plantemangfold, og seminaturlige beitemarker av større tilgjengelighet av fôr.
Jeg viste også at begge habitattyper støttet levering av regulerende tjenester.
Jeg fant høyere karboninnhold i jorda og større kryptogam mangfold i semi-naturlige lyngheier, noe som styrker bevisene for at næringsfattige habitater er viktige bidragsytere til klimastabilisering og vannlagring.
I semi-naturlige beitemarker observerte jeg en synergi mellom egenskapsbaserte indikatorer for nektarressurser og fôrressurser, noe som indikerer at høyere produktivitet ikke reduserer tilgangen på mat for pollinatorer.

Samlet sett viste jeg at semi-naturlige beitemarker og lyngheier i Nordhordland UNESCO Biosfæreområde var støttet leveransen av komplementære økosystemtjenester på tvers av fjordlandskapet.
Jeg understreket at det er behov for videre forskning for å utvide vår forståelse av de komplekse interaksjonene mellom bonden, husdyrene og miljøet i småskala beitesystemer.
Jeg anbefaler at det utformes metodiske rammeverk for å fange opp den iboende variabiliteten i agroøkologiske systemer, ved å utvikle vurderinger på gårdsnivå ved hjelp av tverrfaglige tilnærminger.
Samarbeid om kunnskapsbygging og inkluderende politikkutforming i Nordhordland UNESCO Biosfæreområde er nødvendig for å støtte bærekraftig matproduksjon og bevaring av agroøkosystemer på Vestlandet.

# Introduction {#sec-introduction}

<!-- ## The role of Norwegian small-scale grazing systems in the current global food security challenge -->
## Livestock's part in the global food security challenge

<!-- Should we produce more to sustain more people on the planet?  -->
In the face of the global food security challenge [@kastnerGlobalChangesDiets2012; @moraExploringFutureLand2020; @vanmeijlModellingAlternativeFutures2020], with food demand expected to increase between 30% and 62% by 2050 [@vandijkMetaanalysisProjectedGlobal2021], the initial temptation to dive into a crop-mania has raised some warnings [@foleySolutionsCultivatedPlanet2011; @hunterAgriculture2050Recalibrating2017].
First, the prevalent issue is less a matter of gross production capacity than severe North-South inequalities in its redistribution and availability [@cassidyRedefiningAgriculturalYields2013; @fischerLandSparingLand2014; @tscharntkeGlobalFoodSecurity2012; @westLeveragePointsImproving2014].
Second, there is only very limited potential for the expansion of agricultural lands without conflicting with other land uses [@kimMappingEnvironmentalLand2018; @zabelGlobalAgriculturalLand2014], or critically damaging the integrity of natural and semi-natural ecosystems [@beckmannConventionalLandUse2019; @foleyGlobalConsequencesLand2005; @newboldGlobalEffectsLand2015; @newboldHasLandUse2016].
The livestock sector bears heavy responsibility for the latter, as globalised grain-feed systems have steadily replaced pasture-based husbandry following the Green Revolution [@kastnerGlobalChangesDiets2012; @ramankuttyTrendsGlobalAgricultural2018].
Contrary to initial claims, this transition provided relatively poor returns in calorie supply [@cassidyRedefiningAgriculturalYields2013] or economic profitability for the farmers [@garibaldiFarmingApproachesGreater2017; @jeanneretIncreaseFoodProduction2021].
However, it came at the cost of the decline and degradation of global grassland areas [@bardgettCombattingGlobalGrassland2021; @piipponenGlobalTrendsGrassland2022; @wirseniusHowMuchLand2010], as well as massive land appropriation and environmental externalities, particularly in the Global South [@cunninghamCloseYieldgapSaving2013; @hongGlobalRegionalDrivers2021; @naylorLosingLinksLivestock2005].

<!-- particularly in Europe [@auneLossSeminaturalGrassland2018; @schilsPermanentGrasslandsEurope2022]. -->

## From productivist agriculture to multifunctional agroecological systems

To shift away from a trajectory which places dramatic pressure on the Earth limits [@pelletierForecastingPotentialGlobal2010; @richardsonEarthSixNine2023], livestock production systems must be emancipated from the productivist doctrine [@altieriPerspectivesChallengesAgroecology2024; @ipbesThematicAssessmentReport2024].
For the past decades, a new dominant paradigm has acknowledged the synergy between food security, ecosystem integrity and human well-being [@ipbesThematicAssessmentReport2024], thus defending the potential for win-win alternatives [@fischerReframingFoodBiodiversity2017; @hanspachTradeoffsSynergiesFood2017; @wittmanSocialEcologicalPerspective2017].
These approaches have materialised through multiple concepts - e.g. agroecology [@holt-gimenezAgroecologyFoodSovereignty2012; @wezelAgroecologicalPrinciplesElements2020], diversified farming [@kremenDiversifiedFarmingSystems2012; @rosa-schleichEcologicaleconomicTradeoffsDiversified2019] or sustainable intensification [@prettySustainableIntensificationAgricultural2014; @rockstromSustainableIntensificationAgriculture2017], which share the consensus that food production should be diversified [@petersen-rockneyNarrowBrittleBroad2021; @rasmussenJointEnvironmentalSocial2024], and tailored to the local context [@cunninghamCloseYieldgapSaving2013; @prettySustainableIntensificationAgricultural2014], to support self-sufficient and resilient agricultural systems [@chappellFoodSecurityBiodiversity2011; @gardnerAgriculturalResiliencePerspectives2019].

In this new paradigm, grazing systems are not reduced only to their capacity for sustaining livestock production, but also conceived as a support of multiple benefits to human society [@kremenEcosystemServicesBiologically2012; @leprovostSupplyMultipleEcosystem2022].
The assessment of such benefits largely relies on the ecosystem service framework [@costanzaTwentyYearsEcosystem2017; @haines-youngCommonInternationalClassification2018], or also more recently defined as "nature's contribution to people" [@diazAssessingNatureContributions2018; @ellisEcosystemServicesNature2019], which has been generalised in policy-making since the Millennium Ecosystem Assessment [@millenniumecosystemassessmentmeaEcosystemsHumanWellbeing2005].
Ecosystem services are "ecological characteristics, functions or processes" [@costanzaTwentyYearsEcosystem2017] used as references for the economic valuation of all direct and indirect contributions of ecosystems to human well-being [@haines-youngCommonInternationalClassification2018].
They can be classified into provisioning, i.e. direct supply of energy or material resources (e.g. crops, forage, wood), regulating, i.e. biotic-abiotic processes which support the conditions for human development and prosperity (e.g. pollination, climate regulation), or cultural, i.e. non-material benefits to human mental and physical well-being (e.g. aesthetics, artistic inspiration) [@haines-youngCommonInternationalClassification2018].
The capacity of agricultural systems to ensure the delivery of multiple ecosystem services has been translated in policy-making through the concept of "multifunctionality", formally defined and promoted by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) [@bjorkhaugMultifunctionalAgriculturePolicy2008; @oecdMultifunctionalityAnalyticalFramework2001].
According to the OECD, multifunctionality relies on "1) the existence of multiple commodity and non-commodity outputs that are jointly produced by agriculture; and 2) the fact that some of the non-commodity outputs exhibit the characteristics of externalities or public goods when markets for these goods do not exist or function poorly" [@oecdMultifunctionalityAnalyticalFramework2001].
The realisation of this multifunctionality pathway requires an extensive effort of policy-oriented research, to investigate synergies and trade-offs under different farming models and across multiple ecosystems and sociocultural backgrounds [@egliWinnersLosersNational2018; @rockstromSustainableIntensificationAgriculture2017; @runhaarFourCriticalConditions2021].

## Biodiversity and ecosystem service synergies and trade-offs

There is consensus that higher levels of biodiversity support a wider range of ecosystem services, because the underlying ecosystem processes are affected by different sets of species [@hectorBiodiversityEcosystemMultifunctionality2007; @soliveresBiodiversityMultipleTrophic2016].
A good example of such synergistic relationship is the pollination service:
plant taxonomic and functional richness supports a greater availability, stability and plurality of nectar resource, which favour in turn a more active, more abundant and more diverse community of pollinators [@balfourTradeoffPollinatorwildflowerDiversity2025; @goulnikFloralTraitFunctional2020; @heglandRelationshipsDensityDiversity2006].
In general, biodiversity was shown to be consistently positively correlated with the delivery of regulating and cultural services [@soliveresBiodiversityMultipleTrophic2016; @yangSoilCarbonSequestration2019], but its relationship with provisioning services is more complex [@leprovostSupplyMultipleEcosystem2022].
In semi-natural grasslands, diversity was shown to enhance biomass production and nutritional quality [@soliveresBiodiversityMultipleTrophic2016; @spehnEcosystemEffectsBiodiversity2005], but productivity-oriented management usually results into a loss of rare species [@brunProductivitybiodiversityRelationshipVaries2019; @schulzTradeoffsGrasslandPlant2024].
In shrub-dominated communities, stress-tolerance strategies are favoured to adapt to limiting environmental conditions such as low nutrient availability, water-saturated soil or short growing seasons.
Such strategies, including for instance belowground biomass allocation [@maGlobalDistributionEnvironmental2021], reduced leaf area [@scherrerDisentanglingProcessesDriving2019] or investments towards solidifying compounds (e.g. lignin) [@pierceLeafEconomicsSpectrum2007], limit the availability and quality of palatable biomass [@nelsonPlantFactorsAffecting1994].
On the other hand, shrub-dominated habitats are usually characterised by high cryptogam diversity, which contributes to multiple regulating services such as water retention capacity or soil stability [@eldridgeGlobalContributionSoil2023; @huStructuralCharacteristicsMoss2023].
Ensuring the multifunctionality of agroecological systems thus requires to rely on management strategies which support the diversity of organisms and habitats [@bengtssonGrasslandsMoreImportant2019; @gardnerAgriculturalResiliencePerspectives2019; @tscharntkeOrganicFarmingHarnessing2021].

<!-- - Negative impact of land use intensification on biodiversity and subsequently on ecosystem services/multifunctionality [@allanLandUseIntensification2015; @schilsPermanentGrasslandsEurope2022] -->
<!-- Most studies investigating the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem service delivery demonstrate the potential of a virtuous system under low-intensity farming, where higher levels of biodiversity support a wider range of ecosystem services [@leprovostSupplyMultipleEcosystem2022; @schilsPermanentGrasslandsEurope2022].  -->
<!-- Forage production is determined by both the availability and nutritional quality of palatable biomass, which primarily depend on environmental conditions [@nelsonPlantFactorsAffecting1994]. -->
<!-- Nutrient-poor and water-saturated conditions are limiting for forage production, but the reduced biological activity and the dominance of cryptogams contribute to multiple regulating services such as carbon sequestration [@liLongtermTemporalPatterns2023; @quinCallunaVulgarisdominatedUpland2015] or water regulation [@huStructuralCharacteristicsMoss2023]. -->
<!-- However, limiting environmental conditions, including for instance low nutrient availability, water-saturated soil or short growing seasons, favour stress-tolerance strategies such as belowground biomass allocation [@maGlobalDistributionEnvironmental2021], reduced leaf area [@scherrerDisentanglingProcessesDriving2019] or investments towards solidifying compounds (e.g. lignin) [@pierceLeafEconomicsSpectrum2007]. -->

## Productivity-dependent relationship between grazing and biodiversity

In wet regions, the effect of grazing on biodiversity is usually assumed to follow the intermediate disturbance hypothesis [@gaoCanIntermediateDisturbance2020; @milchunasGeneralizedModelEffects1988].
At moderate intensity, grazing pressure is expected to be strong enough to locally overcome the competition for light, but not so excessive as to homogenise the sward with grazing-tolerant species [@koernerChangeDominanceDetermines2018; @olffEffectsHerbivoresGrassland1998].
This intermediate stage of highest spatial heterogeneity should result in a biodiversity optimum, by favouring the coexistence of multiple life strategies and ecological niches for both plants and animals [@ceraboliniWhyAreMany2016; @steinEnvironmentalHeterogeneityUniversal2014].
Empirical evidence however shows that this relationship is not as straightforward, especially within the low-to-moderate intensity range [@herrero-jaureguiEffectsGrazingIntensity2018; @scohierHowSheepAffect2012; @wangGlobalMetaanalysesResponse2019], as it is for instance mitigated by habitat productivity [@lezamaVariationGrazinginducedVegetation2014; @pakemanLongTermImpacts2019].
In nutrient-poor habitats, the prevalence of stress-tolerance strategies usually limits plant growth rate and reproductive capacities [@diazGlobalSpectrumPlant2016; @pierceLeafEconomicsSpectrum2007], increasing the vulnerability of communities to ruderal and fast-growing species [@pakemanConsistencyPlantSpecies2004; @teuberLivestockGrazingIntermountain2013].
Still, grazing pressure is overall beneficial when temporally or spatially limited, using for example free-ranging livestock [@schneiderEffectsExtensiveGrazing2024] or rotational management [@perottiYearRotationalGrazing2018; @ravettoenriBiodiversityfriendlyRotationalGrazing2017].
Opening the sward facilitates the development of a diverse cryptogam layer [@aldayEffectsLongtermRemoval2021; @austrheimSynergiesTradeoffsEcosystem2016] and widens the range of ecological niches for arthropod communities by enhancing structural heterogeneity [@dennisResponseSpiderAraneae2015; @steinEnvironmentalHeterogeneityUniversal2014].
The relationship between grazing and biodiversity thus depends on both the ecosystem capacity to tolerate disturbance [@piipponenGlobalTrendsGrassland2022] and the management adaptability to abiotic constraints [@plieningerTraditionalLanduseNature2006; @torokGrazingEuropeanOpen2016].

## Diversified management in grasslands: the example of livestock type

<!-- The impact of livestock foraging on the structure and composition of the sward is determined by a combination of morphological (e.g. mouth parts), biological (e.g. dietary requirements) and social (e.g. group interactions) factors [@animutCograzingSheepGoats2008; @parsonsSpatialHeterogeneityGrazing2003; @rookMatchingTypeLivestock2004].  -->
Depending on local cultural heritage and/or national production incentives, grazing systems typically rely on different types of livestock [@rookMatchingTypeLivestock2004].
The direct impact of livestock on the diversity, composition and functionality of semi-natural grasslands is determined by a combination of morphological (e.g. size, mouth parts), biological (e.g. dietary requirements, digestive system) and social (e.g. group interactions) factors, which differ between grazer types [@animutCograzingSheepGoats2008; @parsonsSpatialHeterogeneityGrazing2003; @rookMatchingTypeLivestock2004].
For example, smaller animals such as sheep or goats are more efficient than cattle for reaching less accessible plants and selecting higher quality parts [@gaujourFactorsProcessesAffecting2012; @marrsReleaseSheepGrazing2020].
This foraging efficiency increases their relative consumption of forbs and proteins [@mohammedGrazingBehaviorDietary2020] and enables a more thorough and even utilisation of the field [@tothLivestockTypeMore2016].
In contrast, cattle focus on the most easily accessible forage and tend to avoid species with low leaf/stem ratio altogether [@grantControlledGrazingStudies1996; @rookMatchingTypeLivestock2004].
This more opportunistic behaviour increases the structural heterogeneity of the vegetation cover [e.g. @ravettoenriBiodiversityfriendlyRotationalGrazing2017], which in turns enhances plant and animal diversity [@steinEnvironmentalHeterogeneityUniversal2014; @tonnGrazingInducedPatchiness2019].
The size and weight of the animal also influence the trampling disturbance on soil and standing vegetation [@mayelHowDoesGrassland2021].
Compaction reduces the structural heterogeneity of the soil and the volume of pores, subsequently affecting soil biological activity and the nutrient cycling process [@erktanPhysicalStructureSoil2020; @nawazSoilCompactionImpact2013].
Trampling accentuates soil erosion on steep grounds [@hiltbrunnerCattleTramplingAlters2012] and deteriorates the cover and richness of the bryophyte layer, facilitating the colonisation of ruderal graminoids [@ludvikovaLongTermDefoliation2014].
Finally, cattle's digestive system make them produce feces in greater amounts and with different chemical composition compared with sheep or goats [@lumaretChangesResourcesConsequences1992].
This variation in the availability and quality of dung resource affects the abundance and functional composition of the dung-associated beetle community [@finnExperimentalInvestigationsColonisation2002; @lumaretChangesResourcesConsequences1992].

In agricultural systems, livestock's direct impact on the biotic and abiotic characteristics of semi-natural grasslands interacts with additional management practices, such as field enrichment [@socherInteractingEffectsFertilization2013].
Soil nutrient enhancement favours competitive strategies, leading to an increase of the proportion of nitrophilous grass at the expense of rare species, and more particularly bryophytes [@bochDirectIndirectEffects2018; @gaujourFactorsProcessesAffecting2012].
Inorganic fertilisation particularly was shown to have a detrimental effect on biodiversity [@degraaffEffectsAgriculturalIntensification2019; @kiddImpacts120Years2017], especially because of subsequent soil acidification [@caiIntensifiedSoilAcidification2015; @mengGlobalSoilAcidification2019].
The impact of livestock grazing on biodiversity and the delivery of ecosystem services in semi-natural grasslands thus results from complex interactions between grazer type, field management and environmental conditions.
It is necessary to disentangle these interactions for optimising farming practices according to the local context [@buzhdyganDirectIndirectEffects2020].

<!-- The strength and interaction of each process thus affect the functional structure of semi-natural grasslands, involving potential trade-offs between ecosystem services associated with grass, such as forage production, and the ones associated with forbs, such as pollination [@cutterCattleGrazingResults2022]. -->

## Diversified management in heathlands: the example of prescribed burning

In semi-natural heathlands, farmers have faced the challenge of sustaining forage production without further depleting the already limited nutrient pool [@rupprechtEffectsYearroundGrazing2016].
Over thousand years of history, fire has been found to be a valuable management tool to rejuvenate standing vegetation while redistributing nutrients in the system through ash [@kalandOriginManagementNorwegian1986; @walmsleyEnsuringLongtermProvision2021].
The severity of the prescribed burning is controlled to limit the disturbance on the soil upper layer [@hobbsStudiesFireScottish1984a] and enable the vegetation to regenerate quickly from both vegetative re-sprouting and the seedbank [@mallikEcologicalEffectsHeather1985; @marenPrescribedBurningRole2009].
The germination of *Calluna vulgaris* seeds was shown to be stimulated by smoke, indicating the long-term adaptation of northern heathlands to fire [@marenPrescribedBurningNorthern2010; @vandvikManagementdrivenEvolutionDomesticated2014].
The vegetation is the most palatable for the livestock during the pioneer phase of heath regeneration (0-5 years) [@thorvaldsenGammalnorskSauOg2017], which is dominated by grasses, sedges, forbs and fresh *Calluna* sprouts [@barclay-estrupDescriptionInterpretationCyclical1969].
To maintain fresh forage resource, prescribed burning is usually done in rotations, with new heath patches burnt every year.
This rotational dynamic creates a mosaic-like landscape of heath regeneration stages [@vandvikManagingHeterogeneityImportance2005], characterised by different environmental conditions and successional processes [@fonturbelEffectRepeatedPrescribed2021; @marenChangingContributionsStochastic2018].
The immediate effect of prescribed burning on diversity is usually negative, as fire disturbance generates a niche simplification effect by clearing out standing vegetation and homogenising micro-environmental conditions [@bulanEffectsTwoAcute1971; @murdochDiversityPatternPlants1972].
However, the heterogeneity resulting from rotational prescribed burning was shown to enhance the beta-diversity of plants, beetles and soil fauna [@bargmannEffectsPrescribedBurning2015; @milliganEffectsRotationalPrescribed2018; @rittlTraditionalNorwegianFarming2025].
At regional scale, prescribed burning was found to increase divergence between heathland communities when adapted to local environmental conditions [@velleDoesPrescribedBurning2014; @velleSuccessionPrescribedBurning2014].
Prescribed burning is therefore an important complementary practice to grazing management, as it enhances heathland diversity while preserving the local cultural heritage [@smithResolvingHeatedDebate2023].

## The Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve as a case study

### UNESCO's Man and the Biosphere Programme

Launched in 1971, the Man and the Biosphere (MAB) Programme, from the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO), aims to engage transdisciplinary and action-based research to "improve human livelihoods, and the equitable sharing of benefits, and to safeguard natural and managed ecosystems, promoting innovative approaches to economic development that are socially and culturally appropriate and environmentally sustainable" [@unescoNewRoadmapMan2017; @unescoManBiosphereProgramme2025].
This mission has been carried out since 1976 through the World Network of Biosphere Reserves (WNBR), which, as of November 2025, encompasses 784 sites distributed across 142 countries and a total population of about 300 million people [@unescoManBiosphereProgramme2025].
Biosphere Reserves (BRs) are designated over a wide range of terrestrial and/or marine ecosystems as model areas for experimenting innovative pathways for sustainable development, with the successive strategies of the MAB Programme as references [@barracloughGlobalKnowledgeAction2023; @unescoNewRoadmapMan2017].
The latest Hangzhou Action Plan (2026-2035), the 2015-2025 MAB Strategy and the Lima Action Plan (2016-2025) further develop the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) from the United Nations' 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, in order to facilitate their integration into national policy-making and international collaboration [@unescoLimaActionPlan2016; @unescoWorldCongressBiosphere2025; @unitednationsTransformingOurWorld2015].
Concretely, research in BRs has enabled the identification of identify synergies, conflicts and challenges over land use [e.g. @cusensParticipatoryMappingReveals2022; @konigUNESCOBiosphereReserves2022; @ruiz-mallenParticipatoryScenariosExplore2015; @tamouPastoralistsChangingEnvironment2018] and the monitoring of the efficiency of environmental measures and socioeconomic investments [e.g. @kratzerRuralInnovationsBiosphere2019].

In Western Norway, the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve Area was designated to "be based on the best from the past and [...] pave the way for a future-oriented societal development that ensures the sustainable use of all types of resources for the benefit and pleasure of both the present inhabitants and future generations" [@kalandNordhordlandBiosphereReserve2018].

<!-- Even if the constraining environment of the fjord region has limited mechanisation [@fjellstadPatternsChangeTwo1999], the second half of the XX^th^ century was still marked by a steady process of rationalisation of the livestock production [@jonesLandtenureLandscapeChange1988]. -->
<!-- The change in farm structure led to a general reorganisation of the countryside, with on the one hand the enlargement and intensification of fertile fields, and on the other the abandonment of remote and nutrient-poor areas [@fjellstadPatternsChangeTwo1999; @hamreLandcoverStructuralChanges2007].  -->
<!-- These concurring processes were aggravated by an overall decrease of farming activity, caused by the socioeconomic decline and the ageing population of rural communities [@forbordDriversChangeNorwegian2014; @potthoffNorwegianLowintensityOvine2023].  -->
<!-- The smaller holdings (under 10 ha) were the most impacted, and dropped from representing 90% of total Norwegian farms in 1949 to 53% in 1995 [@fjellstadPatternsChangeTwo1999; @ovreasEndringarJordbruksarealOg2011]. -->
<!-- This change was reflected across the whole fjord region, with a loss and degradation of semi-natural habitats due to woody encroachment [@brynImpactsLandUse2012; @olssonLandscapeChangePatterns2000] and the coarsening of the landscape matrix [@hamrePlantSpeciesRichness2010; @norderhaugBiotopePatternsAbundance2000]. -->
In this context, the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve assumes a leading role for collecting practical knowledge and building partnerships in order to
(1) preserve the inherited ecological diversity associated with small-scale grazing and low-intensity management [@hamrePlantSpeciesRichness2010; @norderhaugBiotopePatternsAbundance2000] ([Box 1](#box-farming));
(2) ensure the resilience and functionality of the agroecological system in the face of upcoming global challenges such as climate change [@liuAssessingEffectsClimate2019; @meuwissenFrameworkAssessResilience2019]; and
(3) support decision-making towards multifunctional farming pathways integrating food security, conservation of the environment and the socioeconomic development of rural areas [@asheimPolicyMeasuresPreserve2020; @bjorkhaugMultifunctionalAgriculturePolicy2008].
The BR framework thus offers opportunities to assess the current ecological state of grazed habitats in Western Norway beyond the dominant conservationist perspective, by investigating the whole range of benefits provided by the farmers and their management [@bardgettCombattingGlobalGrassland2021; @goldsteinIntegratingEcosystemserviceTradeoffs2012].
More generally, investigating the small-scale grazing systems of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve will increase our understanding of the relationships between diversified and low-intensity management and the diversity and functionality of semi-natural grasslands and heathlands [@wehnAdaptiveBiodiversityManagement2018].

::: {.callout-note #box-farming}
### Box 1. Farming system taxonomy {#box-farming}
Considering the diversity of farming systems around the world, a consistent naming framework is necessary to ensure accurate and reproducible comparisons between existing agricultural models [@huberFarmTypologiesUnderstanding2024].
Many terms have been used to describe an opposite to intensive and industrialised agronomic production models, such as, among others, "diversified", "extensive", "organic", "alternative", "agroecological", "regenerative", "sustainable" or "traditional" [@sumbergWhatConventionalAgriculture2022].
Even if these designations usually rely on explicit and practical principles [e.g. @wezelAgroecologicalPrinciplesElements2020], most of them still lack a consensual regulatory framework similar to the one developed for organic farming [@seufertWhatThisThing2017].
This fuzziness has been the cause of deeply rooted biases, of which the Western-centered "conventional" type of agriculture surely is the most representative [@sumbergWhatConventionalAgriculture2022].
According to its literal meaning, "conventional" only designates common practices in a certain geographical area and during a certain time period.
Therefore, there should be no inherent contradiction between "conventional" farming, and for example "traditional" farming, which is still predominant in many parts of the world [@altieriLinkingEcologistsTraditional2004].
However, in the dominant narrative, "conventional" agriculture has been strongly linked to the industrialised model of the Global North, while in opposition "traditional" farming has been rather associated with low-intensity practices, more or less rightfully [@plieningerTraditionalLanduseNature2006].
\
In this thesis, I used "traditional" only to describe formerly common farming practices in Western Norway, which have either severely declined, or disappeared over time, and which are today associated with the region's cultural heritage [@daugstadAgricultureUpholderCultural2006].
Regarding the current dominant livestock model, the most consistent feature of farms in Western Norway is their small production scale according to Global North standards [@klikockaCharacteristicsModelsFarms2021], both in terms of net income and flock size.
The net income for a holding in 2023 was on average 164,500 NOK (approx. 14,400€) [@ssbFarmersIncomeDebt2025], and the average number of heads per holding in 2024 was 25.3 for dairy cows, 11.8 for beef cattle, 49.7 for sheep and 110.6 for dairy goats [@ssbHoldingsAgriculturalArea2025].
In Norwegian, the terms "*småskala landbruk*" and "*småskala beitesystemer*" are used to designate small-scale farming systems and small-scale grazing systems respectively, which are terms also found in research literature for policy-making [e.g. @asheimPolicyMeasuresPreserve2020].
For consistency, I therefore used the expression "small-scale grazing systems" to characterise domestic grazing in the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve independently of farm structure, livestock type or management practice.

### The small-scale grazing systems of Western Norway

Agriculture in Western Norway carries a strong legacy of low-intensity grazing and diversified farming, which have shaped a mosaic-like landscape of remarkable ecological and functional diversity [@austadHumaninfluencedVegetationTypes1991; @olssonAgroecosystemsNeolithicTime1991] ([Box 2](#box-history)).
Even though the constraining environment of the fjord region has limited mechanisation [@fjellstadPatternsChangeTwo1999], the second half of the XX^th^ century was still marked by a steady process of rationalisation of the livestock production [@jonesLandtenureLandscapeChange1988].
The change in farm structure led to a general reorganisation of the countryside, with on the one hand the enlargement and intensification of fertile fields, and on the other the abandonment of remote and nutrient-poor areas [@fjellstadPatternsChangeTwo1999; @hamreLandcoverStructuralChanges2007].
These concurring processes were exacerbated by an overall decrease of farming activity, caused by the socioeconomic decline and the ageing population of rural communities [@forbordDriversChangeNorwegian2014; @potthoffNorwegianLowintensityOvine2023].
The smaller holdings (under 10 ha) were the most impacted, and dropped from representing 90% of total Norwegian farms in 1949 to 53% in 1995 [@fjellstadPatternsChangeTwo1999; @ovreasEndringarJordbruksarealOg2011].
This change was reflected across the whole fjord region, with a loss and degradation of semi-natural habitats due to woody encroachment [@brynImpactsLandUse2012; @olssonLandscapeChangePatterns2000] and the coarsening of the landscape matrix [@hamrePlantSpeciesRichness2010; @norderhaugBiotopePatternsAbundance2000].

::: {.callout-note #box-history}
### Box 2. The history of traditional farming in Nordhordland {#box-history}
The first signs of agricultural activity in Western Norway can be traced back to the early Neolithic period, with the introduction of burning [@hjelleLongtermChangesRegional2018; @prosch-danielsenPalaeoecologicalInvestigationsReconstruction2000] and domestic grazing [@hjelleHesitantHuntersReview2006; @mehlCulturalLandscapeDevelopment2015] which expanded the area of heathland along the coast.
By the time of the middle Neolithic, grazing management had reached the fjord and mountain areas, and by late Neolithic cereal cultivation had also spread in the more fertile, inner regions [@hjelleHesitantHuntersReview2006].
The initial hunter-fishers had progressively settled into fisher-farmers (*fiskarbonde*), who still depended on both sea and land resources to ensure their livelihood [@olssonAgroecosystemsNeolithicTime1991].
<!-- It is during the Iron Age that the traditional infield-outfield system of Western Norway, whose legacy has lasted till the present days, reached its maturity [@olssonAgroecosystemsNeolithicTime1991]. -->
To overcome the low productivity of the fjord region, fisher-farmers relied on a mixed crop-livestock system, involving both nutrient-poor outfields (*utmark*), which were grazed and/or mowed, and more fertile infields (*innmark*), which were cultivated [@austadHumaninfluencedVegetationTypes1991; @indrelidFarmingSystemIts1988] (@fig-succession).
The transfer of manure and mulch from the outfields to the infields created a flow of nutrients and energy which ensured the self-subsistence of farmer communities [@christiansenInfieldoutfieldSystemsCharacteristics1978].
This complementary management shaped the agroecological landscape into a mosaic of pluriactive family farms [@hetlandPluriactivityStrategyEmployment1986; @jonesLandtenureLandscapeChange1988], typically encompassing a few arable fields, several patches of semi-natural grasslands for rotational grazing and/or hay-making, and some forested areas for timber and fire wood [@austadHumaninfluencedVegetationTypes1991; @haugeGaldaneLaerdalWestern1988].
The heathland areas on the outer coast and in the mountains were used as outfields only.
Coastal outfields were grazed all year round, and farmers used rotational prescribed burning to stimulate the growth of young and more palatable *Calluna* stems [@marenEffectsManagementHeathland2009; @thorvaldsenGammalnorskSauOg2017].
Heather was also cut to provide winter forage for the animals [@lundbergAustevollChangingCoastal1991].
The mountain outfields were used for hay-cutting and summer transhumance of sheep, goat and cattle, to allow the recovery of hay-meadows in the lowlands [@indrelidFarmingSystemIts1988; @potthoffChangeMountainSummer2004].
As such, the traditional infield-outfield system in Western Norway utilised the whole west-east gradient of the fjord region, durably imprinting the landscape with a remarkable diversity of semi-natural habitats [@olssonAgroecosystemsNeolithicTime1991].

Source: @brekkeKulturhistoriskVegbokHordaland1993.](illustrations/NBR_IntroHistoryBox.png){width=100% #fig-succession}
:::

<!-- To address both the ecological and economic degradation of rural areas, policymakers have reflected on a new farming pathway based on OECD's multifunctionality [@bjorkhaugMultifunctionalAgriculturePolicy2008; @romstadMultifunctionalAgricultureImplications1999; @ronningenLegitimacyMultifunctionalAgriculture2004]. -->
Despite the post-WW2 agricultural transition, the small-scale grazing systems of Western Norway retain a high diversity of land use and farm structures compared with the more productive Eastern plains [@dramstadTenancyNorwegianAgriculture2010; @forbordDriversChangeNorwegian2014].
Semi-natural heathlands, formerly outfields, are still grazed by free-ranging sheep or goats.
Livestock stays either all year round on the coastline [@lundbergAustevollChangingCoastal1991], or during the short summer season in the mountain ranges to allow pastures and hay-meadows to recover [@olssonLandscapeChangePatterns2000].
On coastal heathlands, some farmers have maintained the traditional practice of rotational prescribed burning (@fig-nbrgrazing A-B).
This management strategy requires specific skills and training, as the intangible cultural heritage from previous generations has mostly disappeared over time [@lundbergAustevollChangingCoastal1991].
On the more productive semi-natural grasslands, the agricultural transition has generated a socioeconomic gradient of farm structures [@blekesauneAgricultureImportanceViability1999].
It includes both full-time and more production-oriented farmers, often but not exclusively associated with mixed dairy-beef systems, and part-time farmers, who rather breed sheep or goats [@asheimPolicyMeasuresPreserve2020; @potthoffNorwegianLowintensityOvine2023] (@fig-nbrgrazing C-D).
At the scale of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve, these different production systems are expected to complement each others in maintaining an ecologically diverse and multifunctional agroecological landscape [@kremenEcosystemServicesBiologically2012; @sollenbergerGrasslandManagementAffects2019].

<!-- Atlantic heathlands are particularly vulnerable habitats as they depend on small-scale production systems which do not ensure the economic viability of the farms in the globalised and highly competitive agricultural context [@hernandez-morcilloPriorityQuestionsScience2017].  -->

# Aim of the thesis {#sec-aim}

This PhD thesis aims to explore how grazing-dependent habitats support biodiversity and ecosystem service delivery in the agroecological landscape of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve.
The research was designed in accordance with the objectives of the TradMod project, which were to provide actionable knowledge to support decision-making for sustainable land use in the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve.
We therefore used an exploratory approach to
<!-- Our work was based on two main objectives: -->
<!-- (1) to estimate to what extent the environmental gradient of the fjord system determines the characteristics of the grazing fields and limits land use across different spatial ranges; -->
<!-- (2) to assess the effects of management, including livestock type, stocking density and prescribed burning, on the diversity, community composition and ecosystem services of semi-natural heathlands and grasslands. -->
(a) capture the diversity of environments and grazing fields typical to the small-scale grazing systems of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve, by encompassing a large geographical area and a wide range of farm structures;
(b) take management-oriented perspectives, with an emphasis on the benefits provided by farming activity, by relying on the ecosystem service framework;
(c) provide a comprehensive data baseline including multiple taxa and ecological indicators, to steer future research in the agroecological landscape of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve.

Our work was based on observational studies of 42 semi-natural grasslands and heathlands, distributed across the west-east gradient of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve.
In **paper I**, we investigated the effect of rotational prescribed burning on beetle diversity and ecological preferences, by comparing active assemblages on patches of pioneer and mature heath in a sheep-grazed coastal heathland.
In **paper II**, we tested the influence of livestock type (sheep, cattle, goat) and landscape zone (coastal, fjord) on plant diversity and on trait-based indicators of forage and pollination services in semi-natural grasslands.
In **paper III**, we explored the cross-scale interactions between the regional environment, the landscape matrix, field management and the fine-scale environment of semi-natural grasslands, and their influences on dominant grass, forb and dung-associated beetle assemblages.
In **paper IV**, we assessed trade-offs and synergies between indicators of diversity, aboveground production, soil biological activity and soil carbon content, across different land uses (infield, outfield) and landscape zones (coastal, fjord, mountain).

These field studies were used to address the following research questions:

- **(Q1)** What is the influence of the regional environment on semi-natural grasslands and heathlands? More specifically:
  - **(Q1-1)** What are the productivity patterns along the coast-to-mountain gradient (**paper IV**)?
  - **(Q1-2)** Can we detect the influence of geographic or climatic factors on the taxonomic and functional composition of semi-natural grasslands (**paper II**, **paper III**, **paper IV**)?
- **(Q2)** How does management influence the diversity and community composition of semi-natural grasslands and heathlands? More specifically:
  - **(Q2-1)** Is there an effect of livestock type on the diversity and community composition in semi-natural grasslands (**paper II**, **paper III**)?
  - **(Q2-2)** What is the effect of prescribed burning on taxonomic and functional diversity in semi-natural heathlands (**paper I**, **paper IV**)?
- **(Q3)** What are the synergies and trade-offs between indicators of biodiversity and ecosystem services among semi-natural grasslands and heathlands (**paper II**, **paper III**, **paper IV**)?

# Research approach and study design {#sec-method}

## Study area

The Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve is an area of 6,698 km^2^ in Western Norway, delimited by the Bergen and Hardanger regions to the south, and the longest and deepest Norwegian fjord, the Sognefjord, to the north (@fig-maptopo A).
<!-- The biosphere reserve is delimited by the Bergen and Hardanger regions in the south, and the longest and deepest Norwegian fjord, the Sognefjord, in the north (@fig-maptopo A). -->
The western border stretches up to approximately 23 km into the North Sea, for a marine surface representing 37% of the total area, and the northeastern border reaches beyond the Stølsheimen mountains, which include the highest relief of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve at 1313 masl.
<!-- ### Geophysical and climatic characteristics of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve -->
<!-- In the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve, the interconnection of fjords and fjord arms results into an intricate landform network (@fig-maptopo A). -->
<!-- This complex landform is associated with strong temperature and precipitation patterns (@fig-mapclimate), resulting from the simultaneous influences of two overlapping gradients of oceanity and elevation [@ketzlerClimateNorway2021].  -->
<!-- On the one hand, the warm and moist air masses brought by the Gulf stream maintain a generally mild and wet climate, which especially buffers temperature annual variations on the coast (@fig-mapclimate B).  -->
<!-- On the other hand, the elevation gradient is associated with a strong increase of annual precipitation, particularly on westerly exposed slopes (@fig-mapclimate A), and a drop of average July temperature (@fig-mapclimate C and D). -->
Fjords are defined as *"steep-sided, coastal erosional troughs which have been inundated by the sea"* after the retreat of the ice from the last glaciation [@howeFjordSystemsArchives2010; @mangerudIceflowPatternsPrecise2019].
The Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve encompasses 11 main fjords, associated with a multitude of fjord arms, which fragment the landscape and generate strong elevation gradients (@fig-maptopo A).
<!-- Due to the Gulf stream's influence, the climate is characterised by generally mild temperatures, especially on the coast, and high precipitation. -->
The climate is largely influenced by the warm and moist air masses carried by the Gulf stream, which buffer annual temperature variation on the coast .
Annual precipitation is high overall, ranging from 1560 mm to 4820 mm, and shows a sharp increase along with increasing elevation (@fig-mapclimate A).
Temperature shows the opposite trend, as both average July temperature and average January temperature decline from 15.9°C to 8.2°C and from 3.2°C to -4.7°C respectively from the lowest elevation to the highest (@fig-mapclimate C-D).

The combination of topographic and climatic factors has generated contrasting landscapes across the fjord region, which can be coarsely divided into three main zones (@fig-maptopo B).
The coastal zone is characterised by a highly fragmented "strandflat" landscape, typical to the Norwegian outer coastline.
Strandflats are partially submerged and gently undulating platforms which result from the last ice retreat [@norgesgeologiskeundersokelseNasjonalBerggrunnsdatabase2023].
On these exposed and rugged grounds, high rainfall intensity and frequency increase particle runoff [@zhangNutrientLossSensitive2020].
In the most extreme cases, erosion processes create nutrient-depleted landscapes of bedrock ridges, shrub-dominated vegetation and mires, typical of the outermost coastal strandflats [@chapinNatureNutrientLimitation1986; @winnerResponsePlantsMultiple1991] (@fig-landscape A).
The inner areas of the coastal zone and the fjord zone are characterised by an expansion of land area and sheltering reliefs, which creates more suitable conditions for agriculture.
These more central lowlands show the highest diversity of land use in the landscape, including forests, shrublands, grasslands and crops (@fig-landscape B).
Finally, the mountain zone encompasses large plateaus above the tree line and up to 1300 masl [@kalandNordhordlandBiosphereReserve2018].
A short growing season, high precipitation and low nutrient availability create landscapes relatively similar to the ones of the outermost coastal strandflats, with high bedrock cover, a large proportion of wetlands and dwarf-shrub dominated vegetation (@fig-landscape C).
<!-- The landscape composition of the fjord region from west to east thus reflects a coarsely hump-shaped pattern of primary production, determining the distribution of species and land uses at regional scale [@karlsenVariabilityStartGrowing2007; @siefertScaleDependenceVegetationenvironment2012]. -->

![Landscape composition (A) on outer coastal strandflats (Øygarden municipality, © M. Kerdoncuff), (B) in the productive lowlands of the coastal and fjord zones (Alver municipality, © M. Demeaux) and (C) in the mountain ranges (Masfjorden municipality, © A. E. Eycott). Pie charts represent average percent land cover in a 1 km-radius area around the sampling location of the 42 sites visited in the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve.](illustrations/NBR_LandscapeFieldTypes.png){width=100% #fig-landscape}

The Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve encompasses 8 municipalities (Alver, Austrheim, Gulen, Fedje, Masfjorden, Modalen, Osterøy and Vaksdal), with additional area from 4 other municipalities (Høyanger, Vik, Voss and Øygarden), totaling a population of approximately 55,000 inhabitants [@nordhordlandbiosfaereWebsiteNordhordlandUNESCO2025] (@fig-mapkommune).
Of the 1,650 farmers in the biosphere area who declared their activities in 2019 [@reiersenBaerekraftVestnorskLandbruk2019], around 530 were keeping cattle for an average of 25.8 heads per holding, among which about 320 had additional milking cows for an average of 21.1 heads per holding.
Around 1100 farmers were keeping sheep for an average of 41.4 heads per holding, and a little over than 200 of them were keeping both sheep and cattle.
Finally, only about 80 farmers were keeping goats for an average of 40 heads per holding. 
Farmers declared on average 6.8 ha of productive infields, ranging between 0.1 ha for the smallest field area and 92.3 ha for the biggest field area.

### Ecological survey in the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve (paper II, paper III, paper IV)

The study area for **paper II**, **paper III** and **paper IV** aimed to be as representative as possible of the agroecological landscape of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve.
Three main factors determined the distribution of the study sites:

  (1) the **west-east environmental gradient**, which we separated into three main regions, i.e. the coastal area, the fjord area and the mountain area, based on the landscape zonation from @uttakleivLandskapskartleggingNorgeLandscape2011.
  (2) the **field productivity**, classified as infields or outfields based on the land cover AR5 classification system of the Norwegian Institute for Bioeconomy (NIBIO) [@ahlstromAR5Klassifikasjonssystem2019]. Infields (*innmarksbeite*) were explicitly designated as "*agricultural lands that cannot be harvested mechanically* \[with\] *at least 50% of the area* \[...\] *covered with cultured grass or pasture-tolerant herbs*". Outfields were located on "open permanent lands" (*åpen fastmark*), briefly defined as "*areas that are neither a bog, agricultural, forest or infrastructure*".
  (3) the **livestock type**, including cattle, sheep and goats, as registered in @reiersenBaerekraftVestnorskLandbruk2019.

Additional criteria of site accessibility were also considered to facilitate field sampling, such as a maximum travel time of 1h from the University of Bergen (except for mountain sites).
Before visiting the fields, we contacted the farmers to have their approval for sampling, to verify management information, and to receive, when provided, advice on most suitable options for study sites.

```{r FieldMeanClimate}
library(tidyverse)
library(purrr)

ecozone <- read.csv("data/cleandata/NBR_FullSiteInfo.csv")
elevation <- read.csv("data/cleandata/NBR_FullArea20x20.csv")
landuse <- read.csv("data/cleandata/NBR_FullLanduse.csv")
climate <- read.csv("data/cleandata/NBR_FullClimate.csv")

# Data table
avgclim <- purrr::reduce(list(subset(ecozone, select = c(SiteID, EcoZone)), subset(elevation, select = c(SiteID, Elevation)), subset(landuse, select = c(SiteID, FieldType)), climate), dplyr::full_join)

# Remove unused sites
avgclim <- filter(avgclim, SiteID != "UC1" & SiteID != "UG1" & SiteID != "UG2")
```

Over the summers of 2019 and 2020, we visited a total of 42 grazing fields distributed in the coastal (n = 19), fjord (n = 17) and mountain (n = 6) areas of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve (@fig-sitemap).
The field seasons ran from mid-June to mid-August, visiting coastal sites, fjord sites and mountain sites in chronological order to account for the timing difference of the spring bloom [@karlsenVariabilityStartGrowing2007].
Sites in the coastal and fjord areas were all located below 250 masl and showed relatively similar climate conditions, with average July temperature around 14°C and average annual precipitation around 1900 mm, except for the annual temperature range which increased linearly with distance-to-sea (@fig-climatedistri).
Mountain sites were located between 600 and 875 masl and were characterised by colder and especially wetter conditions (@fig-climatedistri), with an average July temperature of `r format(round(mean(filter(avgclim, EcoZone == "mountain")$avgtempJuly), 1), nsmall = 1)`°C, and half of the sites receiving more than 3500 mm precipitation annually.

#### Outfields (paper IV)

```{r OutfielddManagement}
#| message: false
#| warning: false

## Packages
library(tidyverse)

## Data loading
siteinfo_full <- read.csv("data/cleandata/NBR_FullSiteInfo.csv")
landuse_full <- read.csv("data/cleandata/NBR_FullLandUse.csv", sep=",")

## Base dataset
management <- left_join(
  subset(siteinfo_full, select = c(SiteID, EcoZone)),
  landuse_full
)
management <- filter(management, SiteID != "UC1" & SiteID != "UG1" & SiteID != "UG2")

### Outfield
outfield <- filter(management, FieldType == "outfield")
### Coastal outfield
coastal <- filter(management, EcoZone == "coastal" & FieldType == "outfield")
### Fjord outfield
fjord <- filter(management, EcoZone == "fjord" & FieldType == "outfield")
### Mountain outfield
mountain <- filter(management, EcoZone == "mountain" & FieldType == "outfield")

```

Outfields were sheep-grazed, shrub-dominated communities (n = 12), located in the outer part of the coastal area (n = 5), in a former forest clearing in the fjord area (n = 1), and in the mountain area (n = 6).

Coastal outfields were Northern Atlantic wet heaths dominated by *Calluna vulgaris*.
The sites were grazed all year round by the Norwegian rustic breed, the Norwegian old sheep (*Gammel Norsk Sau*) [@norskinstituttforbiookonominibioSau2025], with an average of `r op(mean(coastal$FlockSize1_adults))` heads of adult sheep for areas ranging from `r op(min(coastal$SelectedFieldArea_ha), 0)` ha to `r op(max(coastal$SelectedFieldArea_ha), 0)` ha.
Three sites had been grazed uninterruptedly by sheep since at least 2000, one site had been grazed by cattle until 2016, and one site had been abandoned for 50 years until 2019.
Three sites were managed by rotational prescribed burning and one site had invasive Sitka spruce removed.

The single outfield of the fjord area was characterised by a transitional community, with high cover of *Galium saxatile*, *Vaccinium myrtillus*, *Agrostis capillaris* and *Anthoxanthum odoratum*.
The field of `r op(fjord$SelectedFieldArea_ha, 0)` ha was grazed `r op(fjord$YearlyGrazing1_month, 0)` months a year by `r op(fjord$FlockSize1_adults, 0)` adults from the Cheviot breed (*Sjeviotsau*), which had been on site since 1997.

Mountain outfields were subalpine dwarf heaths, with mixed grass-shrub vegetation dominated by *Nardus stricta*, *Vaccinium uliginosum*, *Empetrum nigrum* and *Calluna vulgaris*.
Sites were grazed by free-ranging sheep, with an average of `r op(mean(mountain$FlockSize1_adults))` heads of adult sheep staying on site between 3 and `r op(max(mountain$YearlyGrazing1_month), 0)` months in the summer season.
Common breeds were the conventional Norwegian white sheep (*Norsk Kvit Sau*), the Dala breed (*Dalasau*), which was one of the breeds upon which the Norwegian white sheep was founded, and the rustic English Suffolk breed (*Suffolksau*).
All sites had been grazed uninterruptedly by sheep since at least 2010, and as far back as the 1940s for the oldest record, and three sites used to be grazed by cattle.

#### Infields (paper II, paper III, paper IV)

```{r InfielddManagement}
#| message: false
#| warning: false

## Packages
library(tidyverse)

## Data loading
siteinfo_full <- read.csv("data/cleandata/NBR_FullSiteInfo.csv")
landuse_full <- read.csv("data/cleandata/NBR_FullLandUse.csv", sep=",")

## Base dataset
management <- left_join(
  subset(siteinfo_full, select = c(SiteID, EcoZone)),
  landuse_full
)
management <- filter(management, SiteID != "UC1" & SiteID != "UG1" & SiteID != "UG2")

### Infields
infield <- filter(management, FieldType == "infield")
### Cattle
cattle <- filter(management, FieldType == "infield" & Livestock1 == "cattle")
### Sheep
sheep <- filter(management, FieldType == "infield" & Livestock1 == "sheep")
### Goat
goat <- filter(management, FieldType == "infield" & Livestock1 == "goat")

```

Infields were permanent pastures located in the coastal (n = 14) and fjord (n = 16) areas.
Swards were dominated by either *Agrostis capillaris*-*Festuca rubra* or *Agrostis capillaris*-*Anthoxanthum odoratum* assemblages, with common occurrences of *Holcus lanatus* and *Poa pratensis*.
Average stocking density ranged from `r op(min(infield$AvgStockDensity_perha), 2)` to `r op(max(infield$AvgStockDensity_perha), 2)` livestock unit per hectare (LU/ha) (@fig-sitemanagement).

Sites grazed by cattle (n = 10) (**paper II**, **paper III**) ranged from `r op(min(cattle$SelectedFieldArea_ha), 0)` ha to `r op(max(cattle$SelectedFieldArea_ha), 0)` ha, for an average of `r op(mean(cattle$FlockSize1_adults))` heads staying on field between 2 and `r op(max(cattle$YearlyGrazing1_month), 0)` months.
The most common dairy cow breed was the Norwegian Red (*Norsk Rødt Fe*), but sites were also grazed by Limousin beef cattle, rustic Highland cattle or Aberdeen Angus beef cattle.
All fields had been grazed uninterruptedly by cattle since at least 2011, and as far back as the 1920s for the oldest record, except one which had a 2-year interruption between 2016 and 2018.
All sites were enriched yearly by artificial fertiliser, supplemented by manure for eight of them, and with an additional shellsand-lime mix for five of them to control soil acidity [@sognnesEffectsAddingMoraine2006].
Three farmers also reported to occasionally mulch their fields and only one farmer used herbicides. 
Three fields were resown between the 1940s and the 1970s, among which two were also plowed during the same time period, and three fields were drained between the 1970s and 2000s.

Sites grazed by sheep (n = 11) (**paper II**, **paper III**, **paper IV**)  ranged from `r op(min(sheep$SelectedFieldArea_ha))` ha to `r op(max(sheep$SelectedFieldArea_ha))` ha, for an average of `r op(mean(sheep$FlockSize1_adults))` adult heads staying on field from 3 to `r op(max(sheep$YearlyGrazing1_month), 0)` months.
The most common breed was the Norwegian old sheep, but fields were also grazed by the Norwegian white sheep, the Cheviot or the rustic Spælsau (*Gammel Norsk Spælsau*).
All sites had been grazed uninterruptedly since at least 2004, and as far back as the 1950s for the oldest record, except two sites which had a 3-years and a 5-years interruptions between 2012 and 2015 and between 2006 and 2011 respectively.
Six farmers treated their fields with artificial fertilisers and two of them also used manure, while only one farmer used shellsand-lime mix.
Five sites were mulched at least occasionally, and one farmer also burnt locally to facilitate the breeding of the Northern lapwing (*Vanellus vanellus*).
Three fields were resown before the 1970s and three fields were drained in the 1950s, in 2000 and in 2010 respectively.

Finally, sites grazed by goats (n = 9) (**paper II**, **paper III**) ranged from `r op(min(goat$SelectedFieldArea_ha))` ha to `r op(max(goat$SelectedFieldArea_ha))` ha, for an average of `r op(mean(goat$FlockSize1_adults))` adult heads staying on field from 2 to `r op(max(goat$YearlyGrazing1_month), 0)` months.
The most common breed was the Cashmere goat (*Kasjmir Geit*), but sites were also grazed by the Norwegian milking goat (*Norsk Melke Geit*).
All sites had been grazed uninterruptedly by goats since at least 2015, and as far back as 2000 for the oldest record, and five of them were previously grazed by sheep for various periods between 1969 and 2014.
Five farmers enriched their fields with artificial fertiliser, with one of them also using manure and another one using shellsand-lime mix, and one farmer treated the field with herbicide.
There was no mention of resowing or plowing in the sites history, and to the farmers' knowledge only one site was drained in the 1920s.

### Study of post-fire beetle assemblages in a coastal heathland (paper I)

The ecological survey for **paper I** was carried out at our most maritime coastal outfield, Hopøyna, in the Øygarden municipality (60°38′N, 4°49′E) (@fig-sitemap).
The climatic conditions are greatly influenced by the oceanic regime, with an average July temperature of 13.8°C, an average January temperature of 3.0°C, and annual precipitation around 1900 mm.
The site is located on a 115-hectare peninsula, which is typical of the most exposed coastal strandflats of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve (@fig-oymap B).
The landscape shows two contrasting habitat types, with on the one hand highly eroded ridges, essentially dominated by *Calluna vulgaris* stands, and on the other water-saturated depressions characterised by *Molinia caerulea* mires.
The area used to be grazed by cattle until the 1970s, but was abandoned until 2018 when the current farmer initiated prescribed burning in the northeastern part of the peninsula (@fig-oymap A).
He burnt new patches progressing southwards in 2019, and the same year he brought in 36 heads of Norwegian old sheep for year-round grazing (~0.4 sheep/ha).

## Study approach and indicators

### Ecological survey in the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve (paper II, paper III, paper IV)

We investigated the small-scale grazing systems of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve using an observatory approach to capture the actual management practices of the local farming community.
We relied on multiple taxonomic and functional indicators to obtain a comprehensive assessment of the impact of management on the diversity and community composition of semi-natural grasslands and heathlands (@tbl-papersummary).
The analyses of functional groups and traits, which directly express species' responses to abiotic stress and disturbance [@mouillotFunctionalApproachReveals2013], are particularly pertinent in our study context.
For example, plant functional groups are characterised by different life strategies, which determine their sensitivity to both the environmental gradients [@austrheimPlantDiversityPatterns2002; @klanderudImportanceBioticVs2015] and grazing management [@ludvikovaLongTermDefoliation2014; @tothLivestockTypeMore2016].
<!-- - Plants, and more particularly vascular plants, are the most commonly used taxa for biodiversity assessments in grazing systems [@kokEuropeanBiodiversityAssessments2020] -->
However, whilst plants, and more particularly vascular plants, are usually the main target groups in grazing studies [@kokEuropeanBiodiversityAssessments2020], they were found to be poor predictors of other taxa [@brunbjergVascularPlantSpecies2018].
Arthropod communities, for instance, have shown contrasted responses to management or changes in vegetation structure compared with plant communities [e.g. @hacalaComparativeResponsesSpiders2020; @lyonsImpactsContrastingConservation2017; @wangGlobalMetaanalysesResponse2019].
Similarly, soil organisms were found to be particularly sensitive to land use changes [@keithCrosstaxaCongruenceIndicators2012; @tsiafouliIntensiveAgricultureReduces2015], while providing both supporting and additional evidence to the responses of aboveground taxa [@birkhoferLandUseType2017; @leprovostContrastingResponsesBelowground2021].

Indicators were selected based on their roles in ecosystem functioning and subsequent contributions to ecosystem services in grazing contexts.
We investigated standing vegetation in all papers, particularly analysing the cover (**paper II**), taxonomic composition (**paper III**) and aboveground biomass (**paper IV**) of plant functional groups.
The structure of plant communities provides indication on synergies and trade-offs between ecosystem services associated with different functional groups, such as forage production for grasses, pollination for forbs or water retention for bryophytes (**paper II**, **paper IV**).
In **paper II**, we addressed more directly the delivery of provisioning and regulating services by using plant functional traits to design indicators of forage and nectar resource values.
In **paper III**, we investigated the composition of dung-associated beetle communities additionally to dominant grass and forb assemblages.
Coprophilous beetles ensure a key role in the nutrient cycling process of grazing systems, by transferring fresh dung matter belowground and stimulating decomposers' activity [@nicholsEcologicalFunctionsEcosystem2008].
Instead of focusing on typical "dung beetle" groups (e.g. Scarabaeidae), we took a coarser family-level approach to encompass the functional diversity of the whole dung-associated beetle community [@sigsgaardEnvironmentalDNAMetabarcoding2021].
Finally, in **paper IV**, we explored synergies and trade-offs among ecosystem services using indicators of both the aboveground and belowground systems.
We used the abundances of Collembola and Acari as predictors of soil biological activity [@birkhoferSoilFaunaFeeding2011], which supports the nutrient cycling process and the production of aboveground biomass [@bardgettBelowgroundBiodiversityEcosystem2014].

### Study of post-fire beetle assemblages in a coastal heathland (paper I)

We investigated the taxonomic and functional composition of beetle (Coleoptera) assemblages after prescribed burning using an observatory study of recently burnt patches and unburnt patches in the Hopøyna outfield site.
Beetles are particularly suitable for research on fire disturbance, as they are sensitive to changes in micro-environmental conditions, such as vegetation structure or soil humidity [@bargmannSpeciesTraitSelection2016; @schirmelResponseCarabidBeetles2011].
Beetles are also characterised by high specialisation levels across most families [@betzBiologyRoveBeetles2018; @kotzeFortyYearsCarabid2011], which have shown different responses to fire [@langeEffectsForestManagement2014; @prykeImportanceUsingMany2012].
Previous studies have also demonstrated the importance of functional traits, such as body size or diet, and ecological preferences, such as vegetation structure and soil humidity, in driving postfire recolonisation [@bargmannSpeciesTraitSelection2016; @driscollInteractionsBodySize2020].

## Data collection

### Ecological survey in the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve (paper II, paper III, paper IV)

The data collection for **paper II**, **paper III** and **paper IV** was based on a common nested sampling design (@fig-sampling).
On each site, we defined a representative sampling area of 400 m^2^, which avoided at most exposed rocks, waterlogged ground, trees and field edges (@fig-pic20area).
The sampling area was by default 20 m x 20 m, except in two sites where it was set as 40 m x 10 m instead because of topography and field shape.
Inside of the sampling area, we delimited three plots of 3 m x 3 m, separated from each other by at least 6 m, following the same exclusion rules.
Each plot was divided into nine subplots of 1 m^2^, five allocated to non-destructive sampling and four allocated to destructive sampling (@fig-sampling).
The whole sampling process was designed to be completed within a day for each site.
On site, we collected GPS coordinates, maximum elevation and slope angle between the highest and the lowest point of the sampling area (**paper III**).
Slope aspect and climate data were obtained afterwards, from a digital elevation model of 10 m x 10 m cell size from the Norwegian Mapping Authority [@kartverketGeoNorgeKartkatalogen2023] and from 1 km^2^ daily projections for the period 2010-2020 from the Norwegian Centre for Climate Service [@meteorologiskinstituttNorskKlimaservicesenter2023; @wongGridded112016] respectively (**paper III**).

![Nested sampling design set on a representative 400 m^2^ area in each grazing field. Credits: figure created on Inkscape v. 1.1 (Inkscape Developers, https://inkscape.org).](illustrations/NBR_SamplingDesign.png){width=100% #fig-sampling}

![Sampling area of 20 m x 20 m set in (A) Krossøyna (Austrheim municipality, © A. E. Eycott), (B) Børshøyen (Alver municipality, © M. Demeaux) and (C) Risøyna (Alver municipality, © J. Måren), with the field team at work.](illustrations/NBR_DesignPicSamplingArea.png){width=100% #fig-pic20area}

Non-destructive subplots (15 per site) (@fig-picplot B) were dedicated to the recording of sward composition and structure by the same two observers (Amy E. Eycott and myself) across both field seasons, including:
the identification of all vascular, bryophyte and lycophyte species and the estimation of their percent cover from 0.01 to 100% (**paper II**, **paper III**, **paper IV**);
the estimation of the percent cover of bare ground, rock and litter from 0,01 to 100% (**paper III**); 
the estimation of average sward height by random measurements (**paper III**).
Species that could not be identified in the field were collected for microscopic or expert identification.

![(A) Plot of 3 m x 3 m set in Ostereidet (Alver municipality, © M. Demeaux); (B) Plant community recording in Nedre Vågenes (**paper II**, **paper III**, **paper IV**) (Alver municipality, © L. Voldstad); (C) Aboveground biomass collection in Hopøyna (**paper IV**) (Øygarden municipality, © I. E. Måren).](illustrations/NBR_DesignPicSamplingPlot.png){width=100% #fig-picplot}

Destructive quadrats were dedicated to the collection of aboveground biomass, beetle assemblage and biotic and abiotic parameters of the soil system.
Aboveground biomass was collected within a 0.5 m x 0.5 m quadrat in each plot (3 per site) (@fig-picplot C), and sorted in the lab into cryptogam, monocotyledon, forb and woody vegetation for dry weight measurements (**paper IV**).
We performed two tests of soil resistance to penetration in each subplot (24 per site), by dropping a sharpened metal rod of 1.3 kg (length 43.4 cm; diameter 2.2 cm) from 1 m above the ground through a PVC tube to ensure vertical fall (@fig-picquadrat A) (**paper III**).
Soil was also collected with two types of cores in each 1 m^2^ subplot.
First, three smaller PVC cores of 57.23 cm^3^ (3.7 cm diameter; 10 cm height) (@fig-picquadrat B) were used for the estimation of bulk density and gravimetric water content (36 per site) (**paper III**).
Second, a bigger stainless steel cylindrical core of 200 cm^3^ (diameter 10.5 cm; height 12 cm) (@fig-picquadrat C) was used for mesofauna collection (**paper IV**), from one core out of four per plot (3 per site), and chemical analyses (**paper III**, **paper IV**), from the three remaining cores.
Mesofauna was extracted with Berlese-Tullgren funnels [@tullgrenSehrEinfacherAusleseapparat1918], stored into 70% ethanol and sorted into Collembola and Acari.
The soil for chemical analyses was sieved and merged at the plot level (3 per site).
A subsample of 0.5 L was sent to a certified analysis laboratory for the determination of loss of ignition (LOI) [@schulteEstimationSoilOrganic1996], total nitrogen content with modified Kjeldahl method (NS-EN13654-1:2890) [@bremnerDeterminationNitrogenSoil1960] and available phosphorus concentration with ammonium lactate extraction method [@brayDeterminationTotalOrganic1945].
We finally set dung-baited pitfall traps (diameter 10.5 cm; height 11.5 cm) in the holes left by the stainless steel core (12 per site) to collect ground-dwelling beetles for a full week (@fig-picquadrat D) (**paper III**).
Specimens were sorted at the family level using @duffBeetlesBritainIreland2012a and stored in 70% ethanol.
