### Study of post-fire beetle assemblages in a coastal heathland (paper I)

In summer 2020, we collected ground-dwelling beetles on five replicates of pioneer heath in the recently burnt area of the Hopøyna site and on five replicates of mature heath in the southern area (@fig-oymap B).
The collection period was divided into two sampling rounds of 15 days each between mid-June and early August.
The sampling design was elaborated to fit the narrow shape of the burnt patches, which were mostly restricted to bedrock ridges.
On each replicate, we placed four octagonal sets of pitfall traps every 10 m along a 40 m transect which followed the direction of the slope (32 pitfall traps per replicate).
Traps were plastic cups of 6.5 cm diameter (250 mL) set 1 m apart from each other, and covered with a metal roof in the burnt area to prevent overflowing (@fig-oymap C).
Beetles were collected every week and stored in 70% ethanol after sorting at the species level.
We used the Fauna Entomologica Scandinavica series [@lindrothCarabidaeColeopteraFennoscandia1985; @lindrothCarabidaeColeopteraFennoscandia1986] for the identification of Carabidae, the Swedish Insect fauna (*Svensk Insektfauna*) series [@palmSkalbaggarColeopteraKortvingar1961; @palmSkalbaggarColeopteraKortvingar1963; @palmSkalbaggarColeopteraKortvingar1966; @palmSkalbaggarColeopteraKortvingar1968; @palmSkalbaggarColeopteraKortvingar1972] for Staphylinidae, and the Beetles of Britain and Ireland series [@duffBeetlesBritainIreland2012a; @duffBeetlesBritainIreland2012; @duffBeetlesBritainIreland2020] for all other families.
Staphylinidae were identified by John Skartveit, who also verified the identification of all other species and provided very valuable expert knowledge (see Acknowledgements in **paper I**).
Morphological traits (body size, wing presence) and ecological preferences in relation to moisture and ground cover were collected from the same taxonomic references.

### Farmer interviews

Between October 2021 and January 2022, we conducted phone interviews with the 39 farmers who managed the visited sites to collect detailed information on the livestock and the field management.
We specifically asked for:
the livestock breed;
the number of adult and young animals (**paper III**);
the surface area of the field we visited (**paper III**);
the occupation period of the field by livestock (**paper III**);
the grazing history including current and former livestock as well as past land use;
the type, frequency and intensity of additional management, e.g. fertilisation, mulching and burning.
For the 6 farmers who were unable or unwilling to reply to the questionnaire, we referred to the data collected by @reiersenBaerekraftVestnorskLandbruk2019, which was not site-specific but still provided general information on the related farms (e.g. livestock types, flock size).
We also relied on the open data from the agricultural properties mapping service (*Gårdskart*) of the Norwegian Institute of Bioeconomy [@norskinstituttforbiookonominibioGardskart2023] to retrieve, when available, the field surface area (**paper III**).
Due to incomplete and/or approximate information regarding additional management (e.g. fertiliser amount or frequency), these data were, for most part, unfortunately not included in the analyses.
However, they proved very valuable for providing concrete context to the sites we visited and also allowed us to verify the circumstances of odd values when necessary (e.g. Acari abundance in infields in **paper IV**).

## Analytical methods

Considering the limited site replication (42 sites in total), we favoured robustness over sensitivity when selecting statistical tests and analyses.
All analyses were performed in R versions 4.1.1 (**paper II**), 4.1.3 (**paper I**) and 4.4.1 (**paper III**, **paper IV**) [@rcoreteamLanguageEnvironmentStatistical2024] with R studio versions 1.4.1717 (**paper I**) and 2023.04.2 (**paper III**, **paper IV**) [@positteamRStudioIntegratedDevelopment2024].
Unless otherwise indicated, we usually relied on the *vegan* package [@oksanenVeganCommunityEcology2024] versions 2.6-2 (**paper I**), 2.6-4 (**paper II**) and 2.6-8 (**paper III**) for ordination analyses and used the *ggplot2* package [@wickhamGgplot2CreateElegant2024] versions 3.3.5 (**paper I**), 3.4.0 (**paper II**) and 3.5.1 (**paper III**, **paper IV**) for visual representation.

### Study of post-fire beetle assemblages in a coastal heathland (paper I)

<!-- Since @barclay-estrupDescriptionInterpretationCyclical1969, the post-fire recovery of plant communities in Northern coastal heathlands has been extensively studied, especially in Western Norway [e.g. @marenPrescribedBurningNorthern2010; @marenChangingContributionsStochastic2018; @vandvikManagingHeterogeneityImportance2005; @vandvikManagementdrivenEvolutionDomesticated2014; @velleDoesPrescribedBurning2014]. -->
In Western Norway, research on the impact of prescribed burning on arthropod communities was initiated by @bargmannEffectsPrescribedBurning2015 and @bargmannSpeciesTraitSelection2016, who focused on ground beetles (Coleoptera: Carabidae).
In **paper I**, we aimed to further expand our knowledge of the recolonisation of ground-dwelling taxa after fire, by investigating the activity of the whole beetle (Coleoptera) community.
<!-- In **paper I**, we aimed to contribute to the already extensive literature on prescribed burning in Western Norway, which has mostly focused on the responses of plant communities [e.g. @marenPrescribedBurningNorthern2010; @marenChangingContributionsStochastic2018; @vandvikManagingHeterogeneityImportance2005; @vandvikManagementdrivenEvolutionDomesticated2014; @velleDoesPrescribedBurning2014], and also ground beetles (Coleoptera: Carabidae) to a lesser extent [@bargmannEffectsPrescribedBurning2015; @bargmannSpeciesTraitSelection2016], but other beetle families have yet to be investigated. -->
We compared the diversity, composition and ecological preferences between beetle assemblages collected on pioneer heath patches, one to two years after fire, and on mature heath patches, undisturbed for several decades.
Statistical analyses were based on beetle species count data, pooled at the replicate level (n = 10).
We tested the differences in species richness, Shannon diversity (H) and Simpson's evenness (E~1/D~) [@smithConsumerGuideEvenness1996] with non-parametric Wilcoxon tests.
Beta-diversity was estimated as the group dispersion between patches of the same heath stage based on Bray-Curtis dissimilarity [@schroederHowRobustAre2018], and was compared between heath stages with an ANOVA.
We analysed the community composition according to the date of fire (undisturbed; 2-years post-burn; 1-year post-burn) using Constrained Correspondance Analysis (CCA) with ANOVA permutation test.
We also identified indicator species for pioneer and mature heath patches relying on both the phi's coefficient of correlation [@sokalBiometryPrinciplesPractice2012] and the IndVal index [@dufreneSpeciesAssemblagesIndicator1997], calculated with the *indicspecies* package from @decaceresIndicspeciesRelationshipSpecies2022.
Finally, we compared the distributions of the community weighted means of body size, the wing morphology and the moisture and vegetation cover preferences between assemblages from pioneer and mature heath patches using Fisher t-tests.

### Ecosystem services in semi-natural grasslands grazed by different livestock types (paper II)

In Western Norway, the delivery of ecosystem services in semi-natural grasslands has mostly been studied in relation to land abandonment [e.g. @johansenCeasedGrazingManagement2019; @wehnRelationshipsBiodiversityEcosystem2018].
In **paper II**, we aimed to investigate more specifically the effects of grazing management and the environmental variation on forage production and pollination services.
We compared plant diversity, functional group composition, and nectar and forage resource values of 30 permanent grasslands according to landscape zone (coastal, fjord) and livestock type (cattle, sheep, goats).
We expected trade-offs according to the productivity gradient between the coastal and the fjord areas and to the feeding preferences of the grazers.
Statistical analyses were based on plant species cover-abundance data, pooled at the plot level (n = 60).
The nectar resource indicator was based on the annual nectar productivity per unit cover from @baudeHistoricalNectarAssessment2016 and ranked from 0 to 4 using @melinBotaniqueApicoleApicultural2011.
The forage resource indicator was collected from the e-flora-sys database [@plantureuxEFLORAsysWebsiteTool2010] and scaled from 0 to 3 according to functional type.
We used linear mixed-effects models with the *lme4* package [@batesFittingLinearMixedEffects2015] to test the independent and interacting effects of landscape zone and livestock type on vascular plant species richness, nectar and forage values and on the scores of the Principal Component Analysis (PCA) of plant functional groups, with the year of sampling and the observer as confounding factors.
We analysed synergies and trade-offs by testing correlations between vascular plant species richness, nectar indicator value and forage indicator value with either Kendall non-parametric correlation (richness x nectar), Pearson linear correlation (richness x forage) or Spearman rank non-parametric correlation (nectar x forage).
We finally relied on Multi-Criteria Decision-Making Problems [@yoonMultipleAttributeDecision1995] using the *topsis* package from @yazdiTopsisTOPSISMethod2013 to rank our sites according to their level of within-field synergy between plant species richness, forage resource indicator and nectar resource indicator.

### Cross-scale interactions in the small-scale grazing system of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve (paper III)

**Paper III** was, to our knowledge, the first attempt at disentangling the environmental and management-dependent processes affecting the composition of semi-natural grasslands in the fjord region of Western Norway.
Our analysis was based on a simplified conceptual model of the agroecological system of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve including four spatial scales (regional, landscape, field, fine).
We tested
(1) correlations between sets of variables characterising the environmental gradients (regional, landscape, fine) and the grazing management (field),
and (2) correlations between these explanatory sets and the composition of dominant grass, forb and dung-associated beetle assemblages.
The regional-scale set represented the environmental variation driven by the climate and the landform of the fjord region;
the landscape-scale set represented the composition of the landscape matrix;
the field-scale set included stocking density, livestock type and field area;
finally, the fine-scale set encompassed indicators of sward structure, topography and edaphic conditions.
Explanatory sets were based on quantitative variables (except livestock type), pooled at the site level when necessary (n = 29), and verified for odd distributions and strong colinearity.
Response assemblages were based on plant species cover-abundance data and beetle count data, all pooled at the site level (n = 29) and scaled with Hellinger transformation [@borcardNumericalEcology2011].
We performed preliminary canonical correlation analyses between all sets using the *CCA* package [@gonzalezCCACanonicalCorrelation2023] and the asymptotic approximation of Hotelling-Lawley trace from the *CCP* package [@menzelCCPSignificanceTests2022].
Significant canonical correlations were further analysed with Redundancy Analyses (RDA) [@legendreNumericalEcology2012], tested with ANOVA permutation [@legendreTestingSignificanceCanonical2011], to identify the variables with the strongest explanatory power among sets.

### Ecosystem service trade-offs and synergies across the west-east gradient of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve (paper IV)

In Western Norway, the delivery of ecosystem services associated with grazing has so far been assessed for single habitat types, i. e. semi-natural grasslands and heathlands respectively [e.g. @austrheimSynergiesTradeoffsEcosystem2016; @johansenCeasedGrazingManagement2019].
In **paper IV**, we aimed to explore trade-offs and synergies across the whole agroecological landscape, ranging from coastal heathlands, to lowland grasslands and subalpine heathlands.
We compared the contribution of 23 sheep-grazed fields to indicators of diversity, aboveground production, soil activity and soil carbon content, and investigated synergies and trade-offs associated with field type (infield, outfield) and geographical area (coastal, fjord, mountain).
Statistical analyses were based on plant species cover-abundance, aboveground biomass dry weight, Collembola and Acari count data, and soil loss on ignition, scaled and pooled at the site level (n = 23).
We used Ward's hierarchical agglomerative clustering based on Euclidean distance matrix and the adjusted Wallace index to compare the observed and expected site aggregation, according to field type for the first branching level and to geographical area for the second branching levels [@warrensUnderstandingAdjustedRand2022].
We tested correlations between ecosystem service indicators with Spearman's rank tests [@hollanderNonparametricStatisticalMethods2015], and compared their distribution between primary and secondary clusters with unpaired Mann-Whitney tests [@lehmannNonparametricsStatisticalMethods2006].
Additional effect size was calculated from the Glass rank biserial correlation coefficient [@kingStatisticalReasoningBehavioral2018].

# Main findings and discussion {#sec-findings}

## (Q1) What is the influence of the regional environment on semi-natural grasslands and heathlands (paper II, paper III, paper IV)?

### (Q1-1) What are the productivity patterns along the coast-to-mountain gradient (paper IV)?

In **paper IV**, field type (infield, outfield) was the primary factor of hierarchical aggregation of grazing fields, independently of geographical area.
As expected, this difference was explained by the negative correlation between forb biomass, higher in infields, and shrub biomass, higher in outfields.
We can see that forb biomass indeed follows a hump-shaped pattern when plotted against longitude (@fig-fjordR1 B), while shrub biomass follows the opposite trend (@fig-fjordR1 A).
Our results show how the combination of topographic and climatic constraints in the fjord region limits plant growth in outer areas, while inner lowland areas are more suitable for agricultural production.
This west-east productivity pattern was found to be a major determinant for the historical development of land use in Western Norway [@mehlCulturalLandscapeDevelopment2015].
In addition, we observed that mountain sites showed on average four times less shrub biomass and three times less cryptogam biomass than on the coast (**paper IV**).
Plant productivity in mountainous regions is inhibited by the lower temperatures and subsequent shorter growing seasons [@michaletzDriversTerrestrialPlant2018].
Our results may suggest lower productivity and thus lower regenerative capacity in the subalpine area compared with the coastal area, but we cannot confirm this without taking a more experimental approach.
Still, farm management practices may provide an indication, as only on the coast have farmers developed a tradition of managed burning to suppress aging in heather stands [@barclay-estrupDescriptionInterpretationCyclical1969; @thorvaldsenGammalnorskSauOg2017] (see Discussion in **paper IV**).

We found no evidence that soil biological activity followed a similar hump-shaped pattern along the west-east gradient, as neither Acari nor Collembola abundances showed consistent trends with field type or geographical area (**paper IV**; @fig-fjordR1 C-D).
This outcome questions the suitability of soil mesofauna abundance as an indicator of soil fertility in agroecological systems (see Discussion in **paper IV**).
In @georgeEvaluationMesofaunaCommunities2017, total mesofauna abundance showed a hump-shaped pattern along a productivity gradient ranging from crops to forests, but there was no difference between grasslands and heathlands.
Only their more detailed analysis of trophic groups showed that fungivorous mites (Oribatida) were more abundant in heathlands and bogs compared with fertile grasslands [see also @arnottUplandGrasslandHabitats2021].
In our study context, a finer taxonomic resolution may thus have been necessary to interpret patterns of soil mesofauna across field types and geographical areas (see Discussion in **paper IV**).

### (Q1-2) Can we detect the influence of geographic or climatic factors on the taxonomic and functional composition of semi-natural grasslands (paper II, paper III, paper IV)?

Our results showed no evidence of an independent effect of the regional environment on our grassland sites.
Landscape zone (coastal, fjord) was neither a factor of aggregation of infields in **paper IV**, nor a significant predictor of plant functional group cover in **paper II**, contrary to what could be suggested by a visual observation of the community structure (e.g. @fig-fjordR2 A and B).
In **paper III**, canonical correlations between the regional environment and dominant grass and dung-associated beetle assemblages were significant, but none were supported by their respective RDA models (**ref fig**).
Within the central and more productive lowland area of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve, we can assume that the gradient of abiotic pressure (oceanity, elevation) may be too limited to drive changes in the communities (see Discussion in **paper II**).
Furthermore, for the spatial extent of our study area (approximately 900 km^2^), the influence of regional processes is more likely to be overridden by local climatic and topographic variables [@siefertScaleDependenceVegetationenvironment2012] (see Discussion in **paper III**).
In comparison, ecological studies whose primary aim was to describe geographical effects on grassland species composition usually include stronger environmental gradients [e.g. @zelnikPlantSpeciesDiversity2013] and/or rely on broader areas [e.g. @raatikainenImpactsLocalRegional2007].

The inconsistent outcomes from **paper III** may also suggest that relationships between the underlying regional gradient and plant and beetle communities are characterised by more complex interactions [@dixonhamilCrossscaleContradictionsEcological2016; @petersCrossScaleInteractions2007] (see Discussion in **paper III**).
In **paper II** for example, we observed significant changes in plant functional group cover due to interactions between landscape zone and livestock type:
coastal sites grazed by cattle were characterised by the lowest forb cover, while fjord sites grazed by cattle showed the lowest grass/forb cover ratio.
In an extensive study on meadow communities in Western Norway, @losvikHayMeadowCommunities1993 observed a divergence between coastal and boreal meadows associated with a fertilisation gradient, suggesting that grasslands further inland were, at the time, more productive and more intensively managed (see Discussion in **paper IV**).
In our study area, we found no evidence of such interactions between the regional environment and field management (**paper III**), but we nevertheless recommend to lead further research with a more robust methodological framework [e.g. @redlichDisentanglingEffectsClimate2022] (see Discussion in **paper III**).
It would be particularly relevant to replicate the survey from @losvikHayMeadowCommunities1993, in order to investigate the changes in plant communities and in their relationships with environmental and management factors over time (see Discussion in **paper IV**).

## (Q2) How does management influence the diversity and composition of semi-natural grasslands and heathlands (paper I, paper II, paper III, paper IV)?

### (Q2-1) Is there an effect of livestock type on the diversity and composition in semi-natural grasslands (paper II, paper III)?

<!-- **QUESTION to Inger and Amy**: "In our ecological study, livestock type is representative of both the direct animal impact and the agronomic production system, involving for instance stocking density." - I already described this link in the Intro, last subsection on grazing management in the NBR. Do I need to put a reminder here? -->

Livestock type affected plant functional group cover in our grassland sites (@fig-grazingR3s A), as we observed higher cover of Poaceae in cattle-grazed fields (**paper II**) (@fig-grazingR3s C) and a weak association between cryptogam cover and sheep-grazed fields (**paper III**) (@fig-grazingR3s B).
These findings may indicate a higher trampling disturbance and/or a more intensive land use in cattle-grazed sites, which would favour fast-growing graminoids over the more sensitive bryophyte layer [@kiddImpacts120Years2017; @ludvikovaLongTermDefoliation2014].
However, neither of these hypotheses are supported by our correlation analysis between field management and the fine-scale environment, which showed instead a weak positive association between bulk density and sheep grazing and no link between livestock type and phosphorus availability (**paper III**).

Contrary to @tothLivestockTypeMore2016, we found no evidence of greater forage selectivity or lower vascular plant species richness in sites grazed by smaller livestock (**paper II**) (@fig-grazingR3s D).
The visual observation of plant community structure could suggest a species-specific divergence between cattle grazing and sheep or goat grazing (@fig-grazingR3com A and C), showing for instance lower cover of *Agrostis capillaris* (@fig-grazingR3com B) and higher cover of *Trifolium repens* (@fig-grazingR3com D) in cattle-grazed fields, but our correlation analyses showed no significant link between field management and dominant grass and forb assemblages (**paper III**).
These outcomes were predictable to some extent, as most studies fail to clearly capture a direct impact of livestock type on species richness [e.g. @jerrentrupLittleGrazerSpecies2015] or community composition [e.g. @cuchillohilarioForageSelectivityCattle2018; @fraserImpactSwardComposition2011] despite the evidence of different foraging behaviours and nutritional requirements between cattle, sheep and goats [@mohammedGrazingBehaviorDietary2020; @rookMatchingTypeLivestock2004].
On the other hand, dominant grass and forb assemblages were consistently correlated with a gradient of vegetation structure, which itself showed a weak correlation with the field management (**paper III**).
More specifically, species such as *Poa pratensis* and *Trifolium repens* were associated with fields with higher bryophyte cover and lower vegetation height, which themselves were marginally associated with sheep grazing and smaller grazing area.

Outcomes from both **paper II** and **paper III** thus suggest the existence of a link, at least indirect, between livestock type and plant communities in the semi-natural grasslands of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve.
However, we were not able to determine the direction of this relationship, whether it would reflect livestock's direct impacts, or the farmer choice in selecting the most suitable fields according to grazer type, i. e. more productive grasslands for cattle [@nuthallIntuitiveWorldFarmers2012] (see Discussions in **paper II** and **paper III**).
This mutual interactivity between the livestock, the farmer and the environment is further discussed in the Methodological consideration section of the thesis.
Independently of these considerations, our results show that field management does not override the community variations driven by the fine-scale environment, suggesting that grazing pressure is adapted to the inherent capacity of semi-natural grasslands in the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve (see Discusssion in **paper III**).

Lastly, we found no evidence of a relationship between field management and dung-associated beetle assemblages (**paper III**), despite our expectation that the Scarabaeidae family to be more represented in sites with greater dung availability, i. e. more intensively managed cattle-grazed fields [@barberoDungBeetleConservation1999; @lumaretChangesResourcesConsequences1992].
Not only did cattle-grazed fields show on average the lowest abundance of Scarabaeidae (@fig-grazingR3com F), but Scarabaeidae were only very marginally represented within the community at all (@fig-grazingR3com E).
Our study thus highlights the importance of Staphylinidae, Ptiliidae and Hydrophilidae families within the coprophilous communities [see also @daoudiCompositionPhenologyBeetle2022], especially in the Nordic region where typical "dung beetle" taxa (i.e. Scarabaeinae, Aphodiinae) are poorly represented [@artsdatabankenArtsdatabankenKunnskapsbankNaturmangfold2023].

<!-- Still, we observed that the abundance of dung-associated beetle family was more sensitive to landscape-scale land use than field-scale management (**paper III**). -->

### (Q2-2) What is the effect of prescribed burning on taxonomic and functional diversity in semi-natural heathlands (paper I, paper IV)?

In Hopøyna coastal outfield, prescribed burning reduced beetle alpha diversity at the patch level (**paper I**).
This result was expected, as fire disturbance generates a simplification of the ecological niche by removing the vegetation cover and homogenising fine-scale conditions [@bulanEffectsTwoAcute1971].
However, prescribed burning did not significantly increased patch beta-diversity, contrary to previous findings [@bargmannEffectsPrescribedBurning2015; @brunbjergDisturbanceDryCoastal2015].
We observed a divergence in beetle active assemblage between pioneer and mature heath patches (@fig-grazingR2 A):
recently burnt patches were associated with xerophilous and sun-loving species, while mature patches were associated with strict hygrophilous species.
At the scale of our study site, our findings thus show that prescribed burning favours the activity of beetle specialists associated with dry and exposed micro-habitats (see Discussion in **paper I**).
Similarly to @schirmelResponseCarabidBeetles2011 and @bargmannSpeciesTraitSelection2016, we added to the evidence that moisture and vegetation cover preferences are good ecological predictors of species occurrences after fire disturbance.
We were also able to determine new indicator species of pioneer and mature heath stages, especially among non-Carabidae, addressing current knowledge gaps on the effect of fire on arthropod taxa (see Discussion in **paper I**) [@rittlTraditionalNorwegianFarming2025; @yekwayoOnlyMultitaxonStudies2018].

In **paper IV**, coastal heathlands showed the highest between-site divergence compared with subalpine heathlands and grasslands (@fig-grazingR2 B).
As three sites out of five were managed with prescribed burning, this finding suggests that fire contributed to increase functional disparity between coastal heathlands.
Our results add to the evidence that traditional prescribed burning enhances habitat heterogeneity at regional scale [@velleDoesPrescribedBurning2014], supporting the resilience of heathland ecosystems to changing conditions [@haugumCoastalHeathlandVegetation2021].

<!-- Public support is usually motivated by the conservation interest of semi-natural heathlands as red-listed habitats [@hovstadKystlyngheiSeminaturligNorsk2018]. -->

## (Q3) What are the synergies and trade-offs between indicators of biodiversity and ecosystem services among semi-natural grasslands and heathlands (paper II, paper IV)?

Our sites showed a wide range of plant species richness across the agroecological landscape of the fjord region (@fig-grazingR1 A).
As expected, we observed a productivity-diversity trade-off between semi-natural grasslands and heathlands (**paper IV**).
Semi-natural grasslands were characterised by better forage quality, which was represented by higher forb biomass, while semi-natural heathlands showed the highest plant species richness, which was essentially driven by cryptogam diversity (@fig-grazingR1 B).
This trade-off mostly reflects the life strategies associated with dominant selective pressures, i.e. competition for light in more fertile fields and stress-resistance in nutrient-poor habitats [@conradiResourceAvailabilityDetermines2017; @olffEffectsHerbivoresGrassland1998] (see Discussion in **paper IV**).

Semi-natural heathlands also showed higher soil carbon content than semi-natural grasslands, independently of geographical location (@fig-grazingR1 C).
Furthermore, high cryptogam diversity contributes to a wide range of regulating services [@eldridgeGlobalContributionSoil2023], including water retention capacity [@huStructuralCharacteristicsMoss2023; @michelSpeciesTraitsTheir2012] and soil stability [@silvaEffectMossCrusts2019].
These findings emphasize the conservation benefits of nutrient-poor habitats, for which lower carrying capacity is compensated by higher contribution to regulating services [@huStructuralCharacteristicsMoss2023; @quinCallunaVulgarisdominatedUpland2015] (see Discussion in **paper IV**).
Overall, our study in **paper IV** highlights that, at least to a certain extent, trade-offs are inherent for the different field types, showing that multifunctionality in agroecological landscapes relies on multiple and complementary land uses [@kremenLandscapesThatWork2018; @schilsPermanentGrasslandsEurope2022].

In **paper II**, we found that the nectar resource indicator was positively correlated with vascular plant species richness in semi-natural grasslands.
Our finding thus add to the evidence that plant diversity supports the delivery of the pollination service by ensuring the provision of pollinator food resource [@goulnikFloralTraitFunctional2020; @heglandRelationshipsDensityDiversity2006].
We also observed a positive correlation between the nectar resource indicator and the forage resource indicator (@fig-grazingR1 D), even if the latter was not directly correlated with vascular plant species richness.
This synergy suggests that the biodiversity-productivity relationship in the semi-natural grasslands of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve is currently maintained in a win-win space [@balfourTradeoffPollinatorwildflowerDiversity2025; @gongBiodiversityYieldTradeoffs2022; @ravettoenriBiodiversityfriendlyRotationalGrazing2017].

<!-- At the same time though, semi-natural grasslands showed lower performance than coastal and subalpine heathlands in other regulating services, such as carbon storage or water retention (see Discussion in **paper IV**). -->

# Methodological considerations {#sec-methconsi}

## Heterogeneity and spatiotemporal variability in the Nordhordland agroecological landscape

Our investigation of the small-scale grazing systems of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve highlighted the key role of three main factors:
<!-- The small-scale grazing systems of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve result from mutual interactions between three main factors: -->
1) a strong environmental context, characterised by overlapping oceanity and elevation gradients (**paper IV**);
2) the grazing animal, driving direct foraging and trampling pressures on the field (**paper II**, **paper III**);
and 3) the farmer, who organises management at the field and farm scales (**paper I**, **paper III**).
<!-- An example of co-dependent interactions between the environment, the livestock and the farmer could be described as follows: -->
Our findings suggested that the independent influences of the environmental gradients and field management on the diversity and community composition of semi-natural grasslands were mediated by their mutual interactions at different spatial scales (**paper II**, **paper III**) (@fig-flowconcept).
At the regional and landscape scales, the climate and topography determines the foraging capacity of ecosystems [@fridleyLongerGrowingSeasons2016] (@fig-flowconcept **1**).
In response, the farmer adapts the type (e.g. grazing, fertilisation), intensity (e.g. stocking density) and spatiotemporal dynamic (e.g. field area, occupation period) of management, using for example rotational grazing in semi-natural grasslands, year-round grazing with prescribed burning in coastal heathlands or summer transhumance in mountain ranges [@austadHumaninfluencedVegetationTypes1991; @indrelidFarmingSystemIts1988] (@fig-flowconcept **2**).
The coupled influences of the environmental gradients and farmer management (e.g. fertilisation) determine the distribution of nutrients and biomass at field scale, which in turns affects the livestock foraging behaviour [@hesterForagingBehaviourSheep1999] (@fig-flowconcept **3**).
Within the field, the animal removes aboveground biomass and redistributes nutrients through urine and dung, leading a key role in the ecosystem's energy cycle [@mayelHowDoesGrassland2021; @sittersImpactsBrowsingGrazing2019] (@fig-flowconcept **4**).
Over time, the farmer adapts management according to the livestock production and the fields' capacity to recover [@hylandFactorsInfluencingDairy2018; @robertProcessesAdaptationFarm2016], subsequently renewing the grazer-environment relationship at both the field and landscape scales (@fig-flowconcept **5**).
Whilst predictable to some extent, these three-ways interactions still involve a high level of stochasticity due to the high environmental variability, the partial randomness in livestock foraging patterns, and the relative subjectivity in the farmer's decision-making [@nuthallIntuitiveWorldFarmers2012].
This creates particularly high levels of variance, which were not explicitly accounted for in our study design and analytical approaches.

<!-- (a) At landscape scale, the climate and topography determine patterns of habitat productivity limiting the exploitation of forage resources [@fridleyLongerGrowingSeasons2016; @huangAirTemperatureOptima2019]; -->
<!-- (b) In response, the farmer frames the intensity (e.g. number of animals, fertilisation) and the spatio-temporal dynamics (e.g. field area, occupation period) of the grazing pressure across fields [@hylandFactorsInfluencingDairy2018; @robertProcessesAdaptationFarm2016]; -->
<!-- (c) Within the field unit, the topography and the farmer management determine nutrient availability and biomass production [@maestreAmountPatternGrassland2007], which in turns affect the livestock movement and foraging strategies [@fynnManagingBrowsingGrazing2019; @hesterForagingBehaviourSheep1999]; -->
<!-- (d) The grazing process initiates an energy cycle between the livestock, which removes biomass and redistributes nutrients through urine and dung, and the grassland system [@mayelHowDoesGrassland2021; @sittersImpactsBrowsingGrazing2019]; -->

## Limitations of our study design and analytical approaches

<!-- The complex multi-interactivity within small-scale grazing systems generates particularly high levels of variance, which were not explicitly accounted for in our study design and analytical approaches. -->
We can highlight four major limitations in our methodological approaches:

**(1) Environmental heterogeneity.**
We essentially approached the environmental context of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve as a broad and unidirectional west-east gradient, while overlooking the spatial heterogeneity associated with fjord shape, direction, width and steepness [@bennieInfluenceSlopeAspect2006; @graaeStayGoHow2018; @steinEnvironmentalHeterogeneityUniversal2014].
In **paper III** especially, it could have been relevant to include at least one measure of topographic complexity [e.g. variance of elevation or slope, see @yuMultiscaleComparisonTopographic2015] in the regional-scale explanatory set, which included site elevation as the only landform-related variable.
**(2) Livestock-driven heterogeneity at the field scale.**
Despite the nested sampling design of our ecological study, we did not attempt to investigate sward patchiness in response to livestock foraging [@tonnGrazingInducedPatchiness2019].
In **paper II **, we could have compared the within-field variation of forage and nectar resource values according to grazer types [@duquetteSpatiallyDiscreteDisturbance2022].
In **paper III**, including an indicator of sward heterogeneity may have increased the explanatory power of the correlation analyses between grazing management and the fine-scale environment [@ravettoenriBiodiversityfriendlyRotationalGrazing2017].
**(3) Management-driven heterogeneity at the landscape scale.**
The versatility of the rotational management caused practical limitations for quantifying individual field-scale factors such as stocking density (see Discussion in **paper III**).
We therefore questioned the accuracy of field-level assessments in capturing the spatio-temporal dynamics driven by the rotations, similarly to how, in **paper I**, an investigation at patch level may not have been representative of the mosaic effect driven by rotational prescribed burning [@tammeEnvironmentalHeterogeneitySpecies2010; @steinEnvironmentalHeterogeneityUniversal2014] (see Discussion in **paper I**).
**(4) Biological indicators accuracy.**
Greater indicator sensitivity may have been necessary to capture community responses to grazing management under low disturbance regimes.
Arthropod taxa especially were investigated at rather coarse taxonomic resolution, only down to family-level for beetles in **paper III** and order-level for mesofauna in **paper IV** [@daoudiCompositionPhenologyBeetle2022].
While morphological identification requires a considerable investment of time, resource and expertise, novel DNA methods show great potential for facilitating the investigating of soil fauna [@geisenMethodologicalFrameworkEmbrace2019; @sigsgaardEnvironmentalDNAMetabarcoding2021].

## Optimising the study design towards transdisciplinary farm-level assessments of multifunctionality

Ecological research can support the functionality and resilience of agroecological systems by providing actionable knowledge for the implementation of sustainable management practices [@altieriLinkingEcologistsTraditional2004; @bardgettCombattingGlobalGrassland2021; @gardnerAgriculturalResiliencePerspectives2019].
However, for this knowledge to be representative, comprehensive and applicable in consideration of the local context and stakeholders, research standards should be revised towards more holistic approaches [@sinclairOptionsContextApproach2019].
Key methodological aspects should include:
(1) spatially-explicit analyses, in order to identify the processes driving variance in agroecological systems [@petersCrossScaleInteractions2007] and to disentangle the respective influences of management and the environmental gradients [e.g. @wittmanSocialEcologicalPerspective2017; @redlichDisentanglingEffectsClimate2022];
(2) landscape-scale approaches, with the farm as the main reference unit, to address environmental and management-driven variance not as a bias but as an inherent determinant of agroecological systems [@cloughFieldSizesFuture2020; @deffontainesAgriculturalSystemsLandscape1995; @sinclairOptionsContextApproach2019] (see Discussion in **paper III**);
(3) high resolution indicators, with priority given to taxa contributing to key ecosystem functions such as soil fauna [@bardgettBelowgroundBiodiversityEcosystem2014; @degraaffEffectsAgriculturalIntensification2019], while avoiding groups based on fuzzy definitions unless their dominance in the local context has been confirmed (see Discussion in **paper III**).

<!-- Methodological frameworks should rely on spatially-explicit analyses, favouring resolution over replication and objective-based guidelines over ready-made indicators [@kremenLandscapesThatWork2018; @wittmanSocialEcologicalPerspective2017]. -->
<!-- To address variance not as a bias but as an inherent determinant of agroecological systems, the study design should rely on the farm instead of the field as a reference unit (see Discussion in **paper III**) [@cloughFieldSizesFuture2020; @deffontainesAgriculturalSystemsLandscape1995; @sinclairOptionsContextApproach2019]. -->
<!-- Implicit to this choice is a landscape perspective [@leprovostContrastingResponsesBelowground2021; @leprovostSupplyMultipleEcosystem2022; @tscharntkeLandscapePerspectivesAgricultural2005], which integrates spatial arrangement and connectivity not only as tangible patches and corridors [@baileyInfluenceThematicResolution2007; @evjuSpatialConfigurationMatters2016], but also as flows of energy and disturbance driven by the farmer decision-making [@deffontainesAgriculturalSystemsLandscape1995]. -->
<!-- The inclusion of multiple spatial scales is crucial to identify key processes driving variance in agroecological systems [@petersCrossScaleInteractions2007] and to disentangle the respective influences of management and the environmental gradients [e.g. @wittmanSocialEcologicalPerspective2017; @redlichDisentanglingEffectsClimate2022]. -->
<!-- The determination of suitable indicators requires a more thorough investigation of grassland and heathland communities, as the existence of optimal surrogates of biodiversity response to grazing management has yet to reach consensus [@bucherBiodiversityLowintensityPastures2016; @neffCrossscaleEffectsLand2019]. -->
<!-- Priority should be given to taxa contributing to key ecosystem functions [@balSelectingIndicatorSpecies2018], but I advise caution for selecting target groups based on fuzzy definitions (e.g. the dung beetle paraphyletic group), unless their dominance in the local context has been confirmed (see Discussion in **paper III**). -->
<!-- I particularly recommend to dedicate more attention to the soil system, as scientific evidence on the role of soil organisms in ecosystem multifunctionality is accumulating rapidly, but considerable knowledge gaps remain [@bardgettBelowgroundBiodiversityEcosystem2014; @degraaffEffectsAgriculturalIntensification2019; @wangDiversifyingLivestockPromotes2019]. -->

Last but not least, ensuring the pertinence, applicability and accessibility of agroecological research requires the active involvement of the farmers as knowledge-holders, decision-makers and managers [@bennettLinkingBiodiversityEcosystem2015; @jagerPathwaysImplementationEvidence2020; @rockstromSustainableIntensificationAgriculture2017].
However, several principles should be respected to guarantee inclusive, open, transparent and equitable collaboration in the long-term [@stringerUnpackingParticipationAdaptive2006].
First, farmer knowledge built from empirical, context-specific and community-based learning is as legitimate as and inherently complementary to the fundamental, generalised and discipline-based academic knowledge of scientists [@altieriLinkingEcologistsTraditional2004; @nuthallIntuitiveWorldFarmers2012; @shiSocialInteractionEffect2021].
We ourselves directly witnessed the considerable capacity of the farmers, and more particularly the elders, to recollect details of management history not only for their own fields, but also for the surrounding agricultural landscape [@ianniRevitalizingTraditionalEcological2015].
<!-- Transdisciplinary research is still a vast field to explore [@lacombeDesigningAgroecologicalFarming2018],  -->
Second, research concepts should be discussed, adapted and validated over a common understanding between farmers and scientists [@dickStakeholdersPerspectivesOperationalisation2018; @dramstadIntegratingLandscapebasedValues2001], with priority given to the ones already assimilated in policy-making [@bjorkhaugMultifunctionalAgriculturePolicy2008; @kremenLandscapesThatWork2018].
For instance, @lamarqueHowEcosystemServices2014 showed that, even though farmers were already able to integrate ecosystem services they were familiar with in their decision-making, they still gained from raised awareness on the least known regulating services (i.e. nitrogen leaching, carbon storage).
Lastly, farmer values should be thoroughly identified and associated with the different social groups representing the rural community [@bernuesSeeingNorthernEuropean2016; @busckFarmersLandscapeDecisions2002; @cusensMappingConnectionsIntegrated2023].
The pragmatic approach of farmers driven by material considerations and socioeconomic constraints is essential for assessing the feasibility of scientific recommendations [@marenDiversifiedFarmingSystems2022; @wehnAdaptiveBiodiversityManagement2018].

## Perspectives for the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve

The Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve has a key role in initiating and mediating knowledge co-production between farmers, managers, scientists and policy-makers [@bohnetCocreatingCulturalNarratives2025; @jagerPathwaysImplementationEvidence2020; @lacombeDesigningAgroecologicalFarming2018].
Even though our ecological study assumed a relatively standard, non-participatory research framework, we still aimed to bring a modest contribution to the development of trust and mutual understanding between farmers and scientists.
As a token of gratitude for their involvement, we delivered a personalised pamphlet to each farmer summarising the biological and environmental data collected on their fields.
We also produced a generic version of the pamphlet, based on the whole dataset, for disseminating research achievements with the Biosphere Reserve framework to the general public and promoting our work to potential partners (see Appendix).
From the TradMod project as the first stepping stone [see @cusensParticipatoryMappingReveals2022; @cusensIntegrationMattersCombining2023], the team led by the UNESCO Chair on Sustainable Heritage and Environmental Management is working to expand transdisciplinary research for the sustainable use of land resources in the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve [@barracloughMappingStakeholderNetworks2022; @bohnetCocreatingCulturalNarratives2025].

# Conclusion {#sec-conclusion}

<!-- The industrialised livestock production system inherited from the Green Revolution has failed to ensure global food security, while largely contributing to the current ecological crisis [@bardgettCombattingGlobalGrassland2021; @ramankuttyTrendsGlobalAgricultural2018]. -->
Exploring farming alternatives based on agroecological principles has become a priority to ensure the livelihood of local communities, support the sustainable use of land resources and preserve the integrity of ecosystems [@altieriPerspectivesChallengesAgroecology2024; @ipbesThematicAssessmentReport2024; @kremenLandscapesThatWork2018].
This thesis aimed to contribute to this objective by using the small-scale grazing systems of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve, Western Norway, as a case study.
I assessed how semi-natural grasslands and heathlands supported biodiversity and ecosystem services delivery, by investigating
1) the effect of the regional environment on habitat productivity and the composition of grassland communities;
2) the impact of livestock type and prescribed burning on the diversity and composition of semi-natural grasslands and heathlands respectively;
and 3) synergies and trade-offs across the agroecological landscape of the fjord region.

I confirmed that agricultural land use in the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve is still largely determined by the environment of the fjord region (**paper III**, **paper IV**).
I demonstrated the biological and functional complementarity of semi-natural grasslands and heathlands (**paper IV**), adding to the evidence that win-win strategies promoting biodiversity and multifunctionality in food production systems are already within our reach [@gardnerAgriculturalResiliencePerspectives2019; @kremenLandscapesThatWork2018].
I particularly emphasized the conservation benefits of semi-natural heathlands in 
coastal and mountainous areas, which showed a remarkable diversity of cryptogam species and supported the delivery of carbon and water regulating services (**paper IV**).
I highlighted the role of traditional prescribed burning in enhancing functional diversity locally (**paper I**) [@bargmannSpeciesTraitSelection2016] and supporting ecosystem heterogeneity regionally (**paper IV**) [@velleDoesPrescribedBurning2014].
In semi-natural grasslands, I showed that field management did not override the variations of plant communities driven by the fine-scale environment (**paper III**).
I also demonstrated that, independently of livestock type, these grassland communities were characterised by synergies between vascular plant species richness and nectar resource, and between forage resource and nectar resource (**paper II**).
However, except for cattle grazing which was associated with higher Poaceae cover, independent effects of management factors on plant and beetle communities were at most marginal (**paper II**, **paper III**).
Likewise, I was unable to detect a direct influence of the regional environment on the diversity and composition of semi-natural grasslands (**paper III**, **paper IV**).
I therefore recommend to conduct further research to investigate more thoroughly the interactions between the farmer, the livestock and the environment in the small-scale grazing systems of the Nordhordland UNESCO Biosphere Reserve.
Understanding these relationships will have essential implications for the conservation of 
the agricultural landscape and the development of a sustainable food production pathway in Western Norway.

<!-- showed that grazing management adapted to the capacity of ecosystems allows the spontaneous expression of natural communities (**paper III**), favouring the functional complementarity between semi-natural habitats (**paper IV**) [@gardnerAgriculturalResiliencePerspectives2019; @tscharntkeOrganicFarmingHarnessing2021]. -->
<!-- As such, low-intensity domestic grazing supported plant diversity and synergies between forage and nectar resources in semi-natural grasslands, independently of the livestock type and the farm structure (**paper II**) [@bengtssonGrasslandsMoreImportant2019]. -->
<!-- I also highlighted the crucial role of traditional management practices, such as prescribed burning, for the conservation of heathland ecosystems and their contributions to biodiversity and regulating services (**paper I**, **paper IV**) [@walmsleyEnsuringLongtermProvision2021]. -->

Diversified management strategies ensure the resilience of the food production systems by promoting biodiversity and synergies at local and regional scales [@altieriPerspectivesChallengesAgroecology2024; @rasmussenJointEnvironmentalSocial2024].
<!-- Priorities are to support the viability and diversity of farming models by emphasizing the value of non-marketable commodities, for instance those associated with cultural heritage (e.g. rustic breeds, traditional farming practices) [@marenDiversifiedFarmingSystems2022; @wezelAgroecologicalPrinciplesElements2020]. -->
<!-- by for instance emphasizing the value of the production of commodities associated with cultural heritage such as rustic breeds (e.g. *Gammel Norsk Sau*) or traditional summer farming (**paper IV**) [@asheimPolicyMeasuresPreserve2020; @kvakkestadNorwegianFarmersPerspectives2015; @potthoffNorwegianLowintensityOvine2023]. -->
We encourage further research efforts to investigate already existing models of small-scale farming systems, which are indispensable sources of knowledge for understanding how adaptative management strategies interact with the local context [@bardgettCombattingGlobalGrassland2021; @sinclairOptionsContextApproach2019].
To that end, ecological research must explore transdisciplinary approaches and involve local communities as part of the knowledge co-production processes [@barracloughMappingStakeholderNetworks2022; @bohnetCocreatingCulturalNarratives2025; @jagerPathwaysImplementationEvidence2020].
